Name: George Church
info: George McDonald Church is an influential American geneticist, molecular engineer, and chemist, born on August 28, 1954. He serves as the Robert Winthrop Professor of Genetics at Harvard Medical School and is a professor at both Harvard University and MIT, as well as a founding member of the Wyss Institute for Biologically Inspired Engineering. Church has made significant contributions to personal genomics and synthetic biology, co-founding around 50 biotechnology companies, including Nebula Genomics and Veritas Genetics. His pioneering work in genome sequencing and engineering has led to advancements in next-generation sequencing methods, earning him recognition as one of the most influential people in biopharma and a member of the National Academy of Engineering. As of January 2023, he continues to engage in innovative research and entrepreneurial ventures, including his role as Chief Scientist at Lila Sciences.

Name: Mikhail D. lukin
info: Mikhail Lukin is a Russian theoretical and experimental physicist and a professor at Harvard University, where he holds the title of Joshua and Beth Friedman University Professor. He earned his Ph.D. from Texas A&M University and has made significant contributions to quantum information science, including the proposal of quantum computing mail and the experimental confirmation of photonic molecules. His notable awards include the Adolph Lomb Medal, the I. I. Rabi Prize, the Charles Hard Townes Medal, and the Norman F. Ramsey Prize. Lukin was elected to the National Academy of Sciences in 2018 and is a Fellow of the Optical Society of America.

Name: Robert Langer
info: Robert Samuel Langer Jr. is an esteemed American biotechnologist, chemical engineer, and inventor, currently serving as an Institute Professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He is recognized for his pioneering work in drug delivery systems and tissue engineering, holding over 1,400 patents and authoring more than 1,600 scientific papers, making him one of the most cited engineers in history. Langer's significant contributions include the development of controlled release systems, angiogenesis inhibitors, and innovative drug-delivery methods for brain cancer and diabetes. He has received numerous prestigious awards, including the U.S. National Medal of Science and the National Medal of Technology and Innovation, and is affiliated with various MIT departments and the Harvard–MIT Program in Health Sciences and Technology.

Name: Abraham Loeb
info: Abraham "Avi" Loeb is an Israeli and American theoretical physicist specializing in astrophysics and cosmology. He serves as the Frank B. Baird Jr. Professor of Science at Harvard University and has been the Director of the Institute for Theory and Computation since 2007. Loeb is known for his contributions to the understanding of black holes, the formation of the first stars and galaxies, and the search for extraterrestrial life, with notable works including the books "Extraterrestrial" and "Interstellar." He has received several accolades, including fellowships from the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and the American Physical Society. Currently, he continues to explore controversial ideas regarding the existence of alien spacecraft in the Solar System, particularly through his research on interstellar objects like ʻOumuamua.

Name: David A. Weitz
info: David A. Weitz is a Canadian/American physicist and the Mallinckrodt Professor of Physics & Applied Physics at Harvard University. He has made significant contributions to various fields including diffusing-wave spectroscopy, microrheology, microfluidics, and soft condensed matter physics. Notable for developing Force spectrum microscopy, his research has led to advancements in understanding complex fluids and colloids. Weitz has been recognized with membership in the National Academy of Engineering, the National Academy of Sciences, and the American Academy of Arts & Sciences. He is also an entrepreneur, founding companies such as RainDance and GnuBio, and previously served in leadership roles at several prestigious research initiatives at Harvard.

Name: Dr. JoAnn E. Manson
info: JoAnn Elisabeth Manson is an American physician and professor, born in 1953, recognized for her significant contributions to epidemiology and women's health. She has extensively researched chronic diseases, particularly cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and breast cancer, and is one of the most highly cited researchers globally. Manson serves as the Michael and Lee Bell Professor of Women's Health at Harvard Medical School, a professor of epidemiology at the Harvard School of Public Health, and chief of the Division of Preventive Medicine at Brigham and Women's Hospital. Her notable works include over 1,200 peer-reviewed publications and several influential books. Manson has received numerous awards for her research and public health contributions, including the American Heart Association's Distinguished Scientist Award and recognition as one of the top 1% most cited scientists in the world.

Name: Ronald C Kessler
info: Ronald Borek Kessler is an American journalist and author known for his extensive work on U.S. intelligence and government agencies, having published 21 non-fiction books, including several bestsellers. His notable contributions include investigative reporting that led to significant legislative changes, such as the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act, and the dismissal of FBI Director William S. Sessions. Kessler's works, such as The FBI: Inside the World's Most Powerful Law Enforcement Agency and In the President's Secret Service, have garnered both acclaim and criticism for their insights into the inner workings of the FBI and the Secret Service. He has received multiple awards for his journalism, including two George Polk Awards, and is currently affiliated with Newsmax as a chief Washington correspondent.

Name: Amartya Sen
info: Amartya Sen is an Indian American economist and philosopher, born on November 3, 1933. He has made significant contributions to welfare economics, social choice theory, economic justice, and development economics, notably through his influential works such as "Poverty and Famines" and "Equality of What?". Sen was awarded the Nobel Prize in Economic Sciences in 1998 and received India's highest civilian honor, the Bharat Ratna, in 1999. Currently, he serves as the Thomas W. Lamont University Professor and Professor of Economics and Philosophy at Harvard University, having previously held the position of Master of Trinity College at the University of Cambridge. His scholarship has also been recognized with the 2020 Peace Prize of the German Book Trade for his work on global justice and social inequality.

Name: Jia Liu
info: Liu Jia is a Chinese-born Austrian table tennis player, born on February 16, 1982, in Beijing, China. She began her career in China before moving to Austria in 1997, where she quickly became a prominent player, winning multiple titles at the European Youth Championships. Liu has represented Austria in five Olympic Games from 2000 to 2020, achieving notable success including serving as the flag bearer in 2016. Her accolades include being the European Champion in Women's Singles in 2005 and winning several Pro Tour events. Liu Jia is currently affiliated with the Austrian national team and continues to compete at an elite level in international table tennis.

Name: Michael E. Porter
info: Michael Eugene Porter, born on May 23, 1947, is an influential American businessman and professor at Harvard Business School, recognized as a foundational figure in the field of strategic management. He is best known for developing the five forces analysis framework and the concept of competitive advantage, which have become essential tools in both academia and industry. Porter's notable works include "Competitive Strategy," "Competitive Advantage," and "The Competitive Advantage of Nations," which introduced the diamond framework for national competitiveness. He has received numerous accolades for his contributions to management and competitiveness and currently continues to influence the field through his teaching, consulting, and non-profit initiatives, including the Initiative for a Competitive Inner City and FSG Social Impact Advisors.

Name: Cass Sunstein
info: Cass Robert Sunstein is an influential American legal scholar specializing in constitutional law, administrative law, environmental law, and behavioral economics. He is a best-selling author, known for works such as Nudge and The World According to Star Wars, and served as the administrator of the White House Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs during the Obama administration. Currently, he holds the position of Robert Walmsley University Professor at Harvard Law School, having previously been a professor at the University of Chicago Law School for over two decades. Sunstein is recognized as the most frequently cited American legal scholar and has made significant contributions to the understanding of risk regulation and behavioral insights in law.

Name: Subir Sachdev
info: Subir Sachdev is the Herchel Smith Professor of Physics at Harvard University, specializing in condensed matter physics. He is recognized for his significant contributions to the theory of quantum phase transitions and quantum entanglement, particularly in relation to high-temperature superconductors and black hole physics. Notable works include his book "Quantum Phase Transitions" and the development of the Sachdev-Ye-Kitaev model. Sachdev has received numerous accolades, including the Lars Onsager Prize and the Dirac Medal, and was elected to the U.S. National Academy of Sciences in 2014 and the Royal Society in 2023. He currently serves as Editor-in-Chief of Reports on Progress in Physics.

Name: Raj Chetty
info: Nadarajan "Raj" Chetty is an Indian-American economist and the William A. Ackman Professor of Public Economics at Harvard University. He is renowned for his research on economic mobility, equality of opportunity, and the long-term impact of teachers on student performance. Chetty's notable contributions include the Opportunity Atlas, which maps children's outcomes based on neighborhood data, and his influential paper on intergenerational mobility. He has received numerous accolades, including the John Bates Clark Medal, the MacArthur Fellowship, and the Infosys Prize in Economics, and he is a member of the National Academy of Sciences.

Name: Matthew Nock
info: Matthew K. Nock is an American clinical psychologist and the Edgar Pierce Professor of Psychology at Harvard University, where he also directs the Laboratory for Clinical and Developmental Research. His research focuses on understanding self-harm behaviors, particularly suicide, employing a multidisciplinary approach that includes epidemiologic surveys and clinical studies. Nock has published over 400 scientific papers and has received numerous accolades, including the MacArthur Fellowship in 2011 and four early career awards from various psychological associations. He is also an active consultant for organizations such as the National Institutes of Health and the World Health Organization. In addition to his research, Nock teaches courses on statistics, research methods, and developmental psychopathology, earning several teaching awards throughout his career.

Name: Steven Pinker
info: Steven Arthur Pinker is a Canadian cognitive psychologist, psycholinguist, and popular science author, currently serving as the Johnstone Family Professor of Psychology at Harvard University. He is known for his advocacy of evolutionary psychology and the computational theory of mind, with significant contributions to visual cognition and developmental linguistics. Pinker has authored nine influential books for general audiences, including The Language Instinct, The Blank Slate, and The Better Angels of Our Nature, which explore themes of language acquisition, human nature, and societal progress. His work has earned him numerous accolades, including recognition in Time's "The 100 Most Influential People in the World Today" and multiple awards from prestigious organizations such as the American Psychological Association and the National Academy of Sciences.

Name: Kevin Kit Parker
info: Kevin Richard Parker, born on January 20, 1986, in Sydney, Australia, is a prominent singer, songwriter, musician, and record producer, best known for his musical project Tame Impala. He has released four critically acclaimed albums: Innerspeaker, Lonerism, Currents, and The Slow Rush, with a fifth album titled Deadbeat scheduled for release in October 2025. Parker has garnered numerous accolades, including 13 ARIA Music Awards, two APRA Awards, a Brit Award, and a Grammy Award. In addition to his work with Tame Impala, he was the drummer for the band Pond and has collaborated with a wide range of artists, including Lady Gaga, Rihanna, and The Weeknd. Parker is currently affiliated with Tame Impala, where he continues to innovate within the music industry.

Name: Ashvin Vishwanath
info: Ashvin Vishwanath is an Indian-American theoretical physicist specializing in condensed matter physics, currently serving as a professor of physics at Harvard University. He earned his undergraduate degree from the Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur and completed his Ph.D. at Princeton University, focusing on unconventional superconductivity. Vishwanath has made significant contributions to various areas, including deconfined quantum criticality, Dirac and Weyl semimetals, and topological insulators. He has received numerous accolades, including the 2016 EPS Europhysics Prize and the 2024 Oliver E. Buckley Prize, and was elected to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences in 2021.

Name: Feng Zhang
info: Feng Zhang is a prominent Chinese-born American biochemist and neuroscientist, currently serving as the James and Patricia Poitras Professor of Neuroscience at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a core member of the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard. He is renowned for his pivotal contributions to the development of optogenetics and CRISPR technologies, including the establishment of CRISPR-based diagnostic tools and therapeutic applications. Zhang has co-founded several biotechnology companies, including Editas Medicine and Sherlock Biosciences, to advance these innovations. His numerous accolades include the NIH Director's Pioneer Award, the Alan T. Waterman Award, and election to the National Academy of Sciences, reflecting his significant impact on the fields of neuroscience and genetic engineering.

Name: Markus Greiner
info: Markus Greiner is a German physicist and Professor of Physics at Harvard University, known for his significant contributions to the field of quantum optics and condensed matter physics. He completed his PhD under Nobel Laureate Theodor Hänsch, focusing on Bose-Einstein condensates and bosons in optical lattices, and was involved in the first realization of the quantum phase transition in a Bose-Hubbard system. After postdoctoral research at JILA, he joined Harvard in 2005, where he continues to explore ultracold gases. Greiner has received numerous accolades, including the Outstanding Doctoral Thesis Research in AMO award, the William L. McMillan award, the MacArthur Fellowship, and the I. I. Rabi Prize, and he was elected a fellow of the American Physical Society in 2017.

Name: Miguel Hernán
info: Miguel Hernán is a Spanish-American epidemiologist and the Kolokotrones Professor of Biostatistics and Epidemiology at the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, where he also directs CAUSALab. His research focuses on improving human health through the analysis of healthcare databases, epidemiologic studies, and randomized trials. Hernán is recognized as a Highly Cited Researcher and has contributed significantly to the field through his book "Causal Inference: What If," co-authored with James Robins, and his popular edX course on causal diagrams. He has received numerous accolades, including being elected a Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science and the American Statistical Association, and has served in editorial roles for several prestigious journals.

Name: Edward L. Glaeser
info: Edward Ludwig Glaeser is an American economist and the Fred and Eleanor Glimp Professor of Economics at Harvard University, where he also directs the Cities Research Programme at the International Growth Centre. He earned his AB in economics from Princeton University and a PhD from the University of Chicago before joining Harvard's faculty in 1992. Glaeser is renowned for his contributions to urban economics, particularly his research on the economic and social benefits of dense housing in cities, as well as the historical evolution of urban centers like Boston and New York City. His notable works include the book "Triumph of the City," which explores the role of cities in fostering human achievement. Glaeser has received several accolades, including being elected a Fellow of the Econometric Society and to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and he currently serves as a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute.

Name: Alessio Fasano
info: Alessio Fasano is an Italian-born pediatric gastroenterologist and researcher, currently serving as a professor of pediatrics at Harvard Medical School and a professor of nutrition at Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health. He is the director of the Center for Celiac Research and Treatment at Massachusetts General Hospital for Children and co-director of the Harvard Medical School Celiac Research Program. Fasano is renowned for his pioneering work in celiac disease and bacterial pathogenesis, notably the discovery of zonulin, a protein that regulates intestinal permeability. His extensive research has resulted in over 300 peer-reviewed publications and significant advancements in understanding chronic inflammatory diseases. He has received numerous awards for his contributions to medicine and continues to advocate for patients through outreach and education initiatives.

Name: Jeff Lichtman
info: Jeff W. Lichtman is an American neuroscientist and the Jeremy R. Knowles Professor of Molecular and Cellular Biology and Santiago Ramón y Cajal Professor of Arts and Sciences at Harvard University. He is renowned for his development of the Brainbow neuroimaging technique, which allows for the visualization of individual neurons in the nervous system. Lichtman's research focuses on activity-dependent plasticity in neural circuits, utilizing genetically modified mice and advanced imaging tools. He has received several honors, including membership in the National Academy of Sciences and a Transformative Research R01 Award from the National Institutes of Health. Currently, he is affiliated with the Harvard Center for Brain Science and the Conte Center at Harvard University.

Name: Albert-László Barabási
info: Albert-László Barabási is a Romanian-born Hungarian-American physicist known for his groundbreaking work in network science and network medicine. He is a distinguished university professor and the Robert Gray Professor of Network Science at Northeastern University, with additional roles at Harvard Medical School and Central European University. Barabási is celebrated for discovering scale-free networks and developing the Barabási–Albert model, which explains the emergence of such networks across various systems, including the internet and biological networks. His contributions to network medicine have established important concepts like the diseasome and disease modules, significantly impacting drug discovery and treatment strategies. He is also recognized for his research on nutritional dark matter, which has transformed the understanding of diet as a complex system.

Name: Jonathan Haidt
info: Jonathan David Haidt is an American social psychologist and author, currently serving as the Thomas Cooley Professor of Ethical Leadership at the New York University Stern School of Business. His research primarily focuses on the psychology of morality and moral emotions, notably through his development of moral foundations theory, which explores the evolutionary origins of moral reasoning and its relationship to political ideology. Haidt has authored several influential books, including The Happiness Hypothesis, The Righteous Mind, and The Coddling of the American Mind, with his latest work, The Anxious Generation, addressing the impact of technology on childhood and mental health. He has received multiple teaching awards and co-founded organizations aimed at promoting ethical practices and viewpoint diversity in academia.

Name: Haim Sompolinsky
info: Haim Sompolinsky, born in 1949 in Copenhagen, is the William N. Skirball Professor of Neuroscience at the Edmond and Lily Safra Center for Brain Sciences and a professor of physics at the Racah Institute of Physics at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. He received his Ph.D. in physics from Bar-Ilan University in 1980 and has since made significant contributions to theoretical neuroscience, particularly in the areas of computational neuroscience, neuronal circuits, and memory. Sompolinsky has received numerous accolades, including the Gruber Neuroscience Prize and the Brain Prize, and he currently serves as a visiting professor at Harvard University, where he directs the Swartz Program in Theoretical Neuroscience. His research explores the intersection of physics and neuroscience, focusing on neural learning, sensory representations, and the dynamics of brain circuits.

Name: Hanspeter Pfister
info: Hanspeter Pfister is a Swiss computer scientist and the An Wang Professor of Computer Science at the Harvard John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences, where he also serves as an affiliate faculty member of the Center for Brain Science. His research focuses on visual computing, encompassing scientific visualization, information visualization, computer graphics, and computer vision, with applications in biomedical image analysis and visual analytics. Pfister has made significant contributions to the field, including the development of the VolumePro real-time volume rendering graphics card and the Cube-4 architecture. He has received numerous accolades, including being elected as an IEEE Fellow and an ACM Fellow, and has held leadership roles such as the director of the Institute for Applied Computational Science at Harvard.

Name: Rakesh K Jain
info: Rakesh K. Jain is the Andrew Werk Cook Professor of Tumor Biology and director of the E. L. Steele Laboratories at Massachusetts General Hospital, affiliated with Harvard Medical School. He earned his bachelor's degree from IIT Kanpur and his MS and PhD from the University of Delaware, later serving in various academic roles at Columbia University and Carnegie Mellon University. Jain is a pioneer in tumor microenvironment research, known for his groundbreaking work on drug delivery and the normalization of vasculature in cancer treatment, which has significantly influenced clinical practices. He has authored over 600 publications, received more than 75 awards, and is a member of several prestigious academies, including the National Academy of Engineering and the National Academy of Medicine.

Name: Eric Heller
info: Eric Johnson "Rick" Heller is the Abbott and James Lawrence Professor of Chemistry and Professor of Physics at Harvard University, recognized for his pioneering contributions to time-dependent quantum mechanics and femtochemistry. He has developed significant methodologies, including the "frozen Gaussians" technique, and has made notable advancements in quantum chaos and resonance Raman spectroscopy. Heller has authored over 280 publications, including influential books such as "Why You Hear What You Hear" and "The Semiclassical Way." He is a member of several prestigious academies and has received numerous awards, including the American Chemical Society Award in Theoretical Chemistry. Heller continues to engage in research that bridges quantum and classical mechanics, with a focus on various complex systems.

Name: Amir Yacoby
info: Amir Yacoby is a condensed matter physicist and professor at Harvard University, where he has been teaching since 2006. He earned his bachelor's degree in aeronautical engineering and a master's degree in theoretical physics before completing his PhD at the Weizmann Institute of Science in 1994. Notably, in 2014, Yacoby's research group developed a magnetic resonance imaging technology that allows for nanoscale imaging, providing insights into the atomic structure of individual molecules. He was appointed the Lazaridis Chair in Physics at the Institute for Quantum Computing in 2013 and was named a Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science in 2014.

Name: Jukka-Pekka "JP" Onnela
info: Jukka-Pekka Onnela is a Professor of Biostatistics at the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health and Co-Director of the Health Data Science Program. He is recognized for his innovative research in network science, particularly through the use of cell phone data to study human social behavior and digital phenotyping. Notably, he received the NIH Director's New Innovator Award in 2013 for his contributions to this field. Onnela leads the Onnela Lab, which developed the Beiwe Research Platform, a mobile phone-based digital phenotyping tool for biomedical research.

Name: Samir Mitragotri
info: Samir Mitragotri is an Indian American professor at Harvard University, where he holds the Hiller Professorship of Bioengineering and the Hansjörg Wyss Professorship of Biologically Inspired Engineering. He is renowned for his pioneering work in drug delivery and biomaterials, having developed innovative technologies for transdermal, oral, and targeted drug delivery systems. Mitragotri has authored over 400 research publications and holds more than 200 patents, with his work significantly impacting therapies for conditions such as diabetes and cancer. He is a member of several prestigious academies, including the National Academy of Medicine and the National Academy of Engineering, and has received numerous awards for his contributions to the field. Prior to his current role, he was a professor at the University of California, Santa Barbara.

Name: Andrew Strominger
info: Andrew Eben Strominger, born in 1955, is an American theoretical physicist and the director of Harvard's Center for the Fundamental Laws of Nature. He has made notable contributions to quantum gravity and string theory, particularly in areas such as Calabi–Yau compactification, the stringy origin of black hole entropy, and various correspondences in theoretical physics. Strominger has authored over 200 publications and has received several prestigious awards, including the Klein Medal, the Eisenbud Prize, the Dirac Medal, and the Breakthrough Prize in Fundamental Physics. He is currently the Gwill E. York Professor of Physics at Harvard University and a senior fellow at the Society of Fellows.

Name: Sean M Carroll
info: Sean Michael Carroll is an American theoretical physicist born on October 5, 1966, specializing in quantum mechanics, cosmology, and the philosophy of science. He is currently the Homewood Professor of Natural Philosophy at Johns Hopkins University and has previously held positions at the California Institute of Technology and the University of Chicago. Carroll is recognized for his contributions to various fields, including dark energy, the foundations of quantum mechanics, and the arrow of time, and he has authored several influential works, including graduate-level textbooks and popular science books such as The Big Picture and Something Deeply Hidden. He has received numerous accolades, including being named a fellow of the American Physical Society and awarded the Andrew Gemant Award and a Guggenheim Fellowship. In addition to his academic work, Carroll is a prominent science communicator, hosting the podcast Mindscape and producing educational content through his YouTube series The Biggest Ideas in the Universe.

Name: Bruce M. Spiegelman
info: Bruce Michael Spiegelman is an American biochemist and cell biologist currently serving as the Stanley J. Korsmeyer Professor of Cell Biology and Medicine at the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute and Harvard Medical School, where he also directs the Center for Metabolism and Chronic Disease. His notable contributions include the discovery of PPAR-gamma's role in fat production, the identification of the transcriptional coactivator PGC-1 alpha, and the myokine irisin, which is linked to exercise-induced benefits. Spiegelman has received several prestigious awards, including the Heinrich Wieland Prize, the Frederick Banting Medal, and the Albert Renold Award, and has been elected to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and the National Academy of Sciences. His research has significantly advanced the understanding of fat cell biology and metabolism.

Name: Robin Greenwood
info: Robin Greenwood is an American economist born in 1977, currently serving as the George Gund Professor of Finance and Banking and the Anne and James F. Rothenberg Faculty Fellow at Harvard Business School. He has made significant contributions to the fields of behavioral and institutional finance, particularly focusing on macro-level market inefficiencies, monetary policy, and financial crises. Notable works include his research on stock price bubbles and the impact of retail investors on market dynamics. Greenwood has received the Jack Treynor Prize for his work on capital asset pricing and has held various leadership roles, including head of the Finance Unit at Harvard Business School and chair of the Behavioral Finance and Financial Stability project.

Name: Andrei Shleifer
info: Andrei Shleifer is a prominent Russian-American economist and Professor of Economics at Harvard University, where he has been teaching since 1991. He is renowned for his contributions to corporate finance, financial market economics, and the economics of transition, earning the John Bates Clark Medal in 1999. Shleifer's influential works include key articles on behavioral finance, corporate governance, and legal origins theory, particularly the 1998 "Law and Finance" paper co-authored with Rafael La Porta and others, which has had a significant impact on understanding investor protections across countries. He has been recognized as one of the top economists globally and has over 400,000 citations on Google Scholar as of 2024. In addition to his academic work, Shleifer co-founded LSV Asset Management and has been involved in various projects related to economic development in Russia.

Name: Joanna Aizenberg
info: Joanna Aizenberg is a professor of chemistry and chemical biology at Harvard University, where she also holds the Amy Smith Berylson Professorship in Materials Science. She is a co-director of the Kavli Institute for Bionano Science and Technology and a core faculty member of the Wyss Institute for Biologically Inspired Engineering. Aizenberg is renowned for her contributions to biologically inspired materials science, with 90 publications and 25 patents to her name. Her research encompasses biomimetics, self-assembly, and biooptics, among other areas. She has received numerous accolades, including election to the National Academy of Engineering and the National Academy of Sciences in 2019.

Name: Pamela Silver
info: Pamela Ann Silver is an American biologist and bioengineer, currently serving as the Elliot T. and Onie H. Adams Professor of Biochemistry and Systems Biology at Harvard Medical School. She is a founding Core Faculty Member of the Wyss Institute for Biologically Inspired Engineering and has made significant contributions to cell and nuclear biology, systems biology, RNA biology, and cancer therapeutics. Notable works include her research on synthetic biology, carbon fixation, and gene regulation, which have implications for developing novel therapies and understanding disease mechanisms. Silver has received numerous accolades, including the NSF Presidential Young Investigator Award, the NIH MERIT award, and election to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and the National Academy of Sciences. She is also recognized for her role in graduate education as the first director of the Harvard University Graduate Program in Systems Biology.

Name: Xiaowei Zhuang
info: Xiaowei Zhuang is a Chinese-American biophysicist and the David B. Arnold Jr. Professor of Science at Harvard University, where she also holds positions in Chemistry and Chemical Biology and Physics. She is renowned for her pioneering work in Stochastic Optical Reconstruction Microscopy (STORM), a super-resolution fluorescence microscopy technique that has enabled the visualization of novel cellular structures. Zhuang's contributions to imaging techniques have earned her prestigious accolades, including the 2019 Breakthrough Prize in Life Sciences and the 2020 Vilcek Foundation Prize in Biomedical Science. Her research continues to advance the understanding of biological systems at the molecular level, and she is currently an Investigator at the Howard Hughes Medical Institute.

Name: Mehmet Toner
info: Mehmet Toner is a Turkish biomedical engineer born in 1958, currently serving as the Helen Andrus Benedict Professor of Surgery at Massachusetts General Hospital and Harvard Medical School, with a joint appointment at the Harvard-MIT Division of Health Sciences and Technology. He co-founded the Center for Engineering in Medicine and directs the Biomedical Engineering Research and Education Program at MGH. Toner has significantly contributed to cryobiology, biopreservation, and biomedical engineering, developing microtechnology and nanotechnology applications for clinical medicine, particularly in cancer treatment. He has received numerous accolades, including membership in the National Academy of Medicine, the National Academy of Engineering, and the National Academy of Inventors, and he is recognized for his work on the CTC-chip for cancer detection and rapid testing for SARS-CoV-2 during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Name: Rachel I. Wilson
info: Rachel Alexandra Wilson is a Canadian actress born on May 12, 1977, in Ottawa, Ontario. She began her acting career at the age of 12 and has worked extensively in Toronto, Vancouver, and Los Angeles. Wilson is best known for her roles as Heather in the animated series Total Drama and Tamira Goldstein in Breaker High. Her notable television credits include Dr. Nikki Renholds on CBC's Republic of Doyle and appearances in various series such as Judging Amy and Charmed. She has also starred in films that were featured at the Toronto International Film Festival.

Name: Katia Bertoldi
info: Katia Bertoldi is the William and Ami Kuan Danoff Professor of Applied Mechanics at Harvard University, where she leads the Bertoldi group focused on the mechanics of materials and structures. Her research emphasizes the design of materials with unique meso-structures that yield innovative behaviors at the macroscale, particularly through the exploration of mechanical and acoustic properties. Notable contributions include her work on pneumatic networks for soft robotics and topological phononic crystals. Bertoldi has received several accolades, including the National Science Foundation CAREER Award and the American Society of Mechanical Engineers Hughes Young Investigator Award, and she is a Fellow of the American Physical Society.

Name: Hongkun Park
info: Hongkun Park is a South Korean-born American chemist and physicist, currently serving as the Mark Hyman Jr. Professor of Chemistry and Professor of Physics at Harvard University. He is recognized for his significant contributions to nanoscience, quantum information science, quantum materials, and bio-nano interfaces. Park's pioneering work includes the development of single-molecule transistors and advancements in quantum sensing, notably demonstrating room-temperature nuclear magnetic resonance detection of single proteins. His accolades include the Ho-Am Prize in Science, the NIH Director's Pioneer Award, and election as a Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. He is also a co-founder of Quantum Diamond Technologies, Inc. and CytoTronics, and has held advisory roles in various scientific organizations.

Name: Thomas Joiner
info: Thomas Joiner is an American academic psychologist renowned for his expertise in suicide research. He serves as the Robert O. Lawton Professor of Psychology at Florida State University, where he leads the Laboratory for the Study of the Psychology and Neurobiology of Mood Disorders, Suicide, and Related Conditions. Joiner is the author of significant works including Why People Die by Suicide and Myths about Suicide, and he currently holds the position of editor-in-chief for the journal Suicide and Life-Threatening Behavior. His interpersonal theory of suicide offers a comprehensive framework for understanding the factors that contribute to suicidal behavior. He earned his Ph.D. from the University of Texas at Austin.

Name: alberto alesina
info: Alberto Alesina was an influential Italian economist who served as the Nathaniel Ropes Professor of Political Economy at Harvard University from 2003 until his death in 2020. Renowned for his pioneering work in political economy, Alesina utilized economic methodologies to analyze social and political phenomena, significantly shaping the modern field. His notable contributions include research on fiscal policy, immigration, and the political economy of business cycles, with key publications such as "Large Changes in Fiscal Policy: Taxes Versus Spending" and "The Size of Nations." Alesina received several accolades, including election to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and the Econometric Society, and he was recognized as a leading candidate for the Nobel Prize in Economic Sciences. At the time of his passing, he was actively involved in research and teaching at Harvard, where a seminar was later renamed in his honor.

Name: Peter Libby
info: Peter Libby is an American physician specializing in atherosclerosis, cardiology, and preventive cardiology. He serves as the Mallinckrodt Professor of Medicine at Harvard Medical School and is affiliated with Brigham and Women's Hospital. Libby is recognized for his significant contributions to the understanding of cardiovascular disease and has authored numerous key works in the field.

Name: Christopher D Manning
info: Christopher David Manning is a prominent computer scientist and applied linguist, recognized for his influential research in natural language processing, artificial intelligence, and machine learning. He serves as the Director of the Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory and holds the Thomas M. Siebel Professorship in Machine Learning at Stanford University, where he is also a professor of Linguistics and Computer Science. Manning is known for co-developing significant technologies such as GloVe word vectors and various neural network architectures, and he has authored key textbooks including Foundations of Statistical Natural Language Processing and Introduction to Information Retrieval. He has received numerous accolades, including being elected an AAAI Fellow and awarded the IEEE John von Neumann Medal in 2024. Additionally, Manning has contributed to the field through his involvement in open-source software development and has mentored several notable PhD students.

Name: John P.A. Ioannidis
info: John P. A. Ioannidis is a Greek-American physician-scientist and professor at Stanford University, renowned for his work in evidence-based medicine, epidemiology, and clinical research. He is particularly noted for his contributions to meta-research, focusing on the reliability and validity of scientific studies. His influential 2005 essay "Why Most Published Research Findings Are False" remains one of the most accessed articles in the history of the Public Library of Science. Ioannidis has served on the editorial boards of numerous prestigious journals and has received significant recognition for his research, including an h-index of 239. Currently, he holds multiple academic appointments at Stanford, where he directs the Stanford Prevention Research Center and co-directs the Meta-Research Innovation Center.

Name: Michal Kosinski
info: Michal Kosinski is an associate professor of Organizational Behavior at Stanford University, specializing in computational psychology and psychometrics. His research focuses on the psychological processes in Large Language Models and the use of AI and big data to predict human behavior. Kosinski co-authored the textbook Modern Psychometrics and has published over 90 peer-reviewed papers, which have garnered more than 21,000 citations. He is recognized as one of the top 1% of Highly Cited Researchers and has contributed significantly to discussions on privacy risks related to digital behavior, notably warning against Cambridge Analytica. Kosinski holds a doctorate in psychology from the University of Cambridge and has previously worked at Stanford's Computer Science Department and Microsoft Research.

Name: Jure Leskovec
info: Jure Leskovec is a Slovenian-American computer scientist and entrepreneur, currently an associate professor of Computer Science at Stanford University, where he specializes in networks. He earned his Diploma in Computer Science from the University of Ljubljana and a PhD in Computational and Statistical Learning from Carnegie Mellon University. His research focuses on applied machine learning and data science for large interconnected systems, with applications in areas such as commonsense reasoning and computational biology. Notable contributions include his work on node2vec and inductive representation learning on large graphs. Leskovec has received several awards, including the Microsoft Research Faculty Fellowship and the SIGKDD Innovation Award, and he previously served as chief scientist at Pinterest and co-founded the AI startup Kumo.

Name: Andrew Huberman
info: Andrew David Huberman is an American neuroscientist and podcaster, currently serving as an associate professor of neurobiology and ophthalmology at the Stanford University School of Medicine. He earned his B.A. in psychology from UC Santa Barbara, an M.A. from UC Berkeley, and a Ph.D. in neuroscience from UC Davis. Huberman's research focuses on vision regeneration, stress mitigation, and non-pharmacological interventions for anxiety, with notable contributions including the use of virtual reality for retinal neuron regrowth. He is also the host of the popular podcast Huberman Lab, which has gained significant attention for its health and science discussions, although it has faced criticism for promoting dietary supplements and controversial health views. Huberman has received several awards, including the Cogan Award for Contributions to Vision Science and the Pew Biomedical Scholar Award.

Name: Andrew Ng
info: Andrew Ng is a prominent British-American computer scientist and technology entrepreneur, primarily focused on machine learning and artificial intelligence. He co-founded Google Brain and served as Chief Scientist at Baidu, where he significantly expanded the company's AI capabilities. Ng is an adjunct professor at Stanford University, where he previously directed the Stanford AI Lab and taught the highly popular machine learning course. He is also a co-founder of Coursera and DeepLearning.AI, through which he has educated millions in AI and deep learning. Recognized as one of the most influential figures in technology, Ng has received numerous accolades, including being named in Time magazine's 100 Most Influential People and the Time100 AI Most Influential People in 2023. Currently, he leads the AI Fund, an investment initiative supporting AI startups.

Name: Geoffrey Hinton
info: Geoffrey Hinton is a British-Canadian computer scientist and cognitive psychologist renowned for his pioneering contributions to artificial neural networks, earning him the title "the Godfather of AI." He is currently University Professor Emeritus at the University of Toronto and was previously affiliated with Google Brain until his resignation in May 2023, motivated by concerns over AI risks. Hinton co-authored a seminal paper on the backpropagation algorithm in 1986 and led the development of AlexNet, a landmark achievement in computer vision. He received the 2018 Turing Award alongside Yoshua Bengio and Yann LeCun for their work in deep learning and was awarded the 2024 Nobel Prize in Physics for foundational discoveries in machine learning. Hinton continues to advocate for AI safety and ethical guidelines in the field.

Name: Carolyn Bertozzi
info: Carolyn Ruth Bertozzi is an American chemist and Nobel laureate recognized for her pioneering work in bioorthogonal chemistry, which enables chemical reactions in living systems without disrupting cellular processes. Her research focuses on glycobiology, particularly the role of cell surface sugars in diseases such as cancer and viral infections. Bertozzi holds the Anne T. and Robert M. Bass Professorship at Stanford University and is an Investigator at the Howard Hughes Medical Institute. She has received numerous accolades, including the MacArthur Fellowship and the Lemelson–MIT Prize, and was awarded the 2022 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for her contributions to click chemistry and bioorthogonal chemistry.

Name: Zhenan Bao
info: Zhenan Bao is a Chinese-born American chemical engineer and the K. K. Lee Professor of Chemical Engineering at Stanford University, where she also holds courtesy appointments in Chemistry and Material Science and Engineering. Known for her pioneering work on organic field-effect transistors and organic semiconductors, her research has significant implications for flexible electronics and electronic skin. Bao has received numerous accolades, including election to the U.S. National Academy of Engineering and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, as well as the L'Oréal-UNESCO Awards for Women in Science. She is actively involved in various advisory roles and has co-founded startups in Silicon Valley, focusing on innovative materials for electronics and biomedical applications.

Name: Joseph C. Wu
info: Wu Jau-shieh, also known as Joseph Wu, is a Taiwanese political scientist and diplomat currently serving as the secretary-general of the National Security Council since 2024. He previously held the position of foreign minister from 2018 to 2024 and was secretary-general to the presidential office under Tsai Ing-wen from 2017 to 2018. Wu earned his Ph.D. in political science from Ohio State University, focusing on comparative politics and international relations, and has contributed significantly to discussions on Taiwan's democratization and cross-strait relations. He has been recognized with the Order of Brilliant Star with Special Grand Cordon in 2024 and has published articles addressing Taiwan's geopolitical stance, including pieces in Foreign Affairs and The Hill.

Name: Dan Boneh
info: Dan Boneh is an Israeli-American professor specializing in applied cryptography and computer security at Stanford University, where he has been a faculty member since 1997. He earned his Ph.D. from Princeton University in 1996 and is a key figure in the development of pairing-based cryptography and identity-based encryption. Boneh has co-directed the Center for Blockchain Research at Stanford and has made significant contributions to various areas of cryptography, including homomorphic encryption and timing attacks. His notable awards include election to the National Academy of Engineering and the ACM Prize in Computing. He is currently involved in teaching online courses and has co-founded a successful cybersecurity company.

Name: Garry Nolan
info: Garry P. Nolan is a British-American immunologist and academic, currently serving as the Rachford and Carlota A. Harris Professor Endowed Chair in the Department of Pathology at Stanford University School of Medicine. He has made significant contributions to the fields of autoimmunity, cancer, and systems immunology, and has founded several biotechnology companies, including Rigel, Inc. and Akoya Biosciences. In addition to his scientific work, Nolan has gained attention for his investigations into ufology, advocating for research into unidentified aerial phenomena and extraterrestrial intelligence. He co-founded The Sol Foundation in 2023 to promote scientific assessment of UAP phenomena and has received the United States Department of Defense Teal Innovator Award in recognition of his contributions.

Name: Oussama Khatib
info: Oussama Khatib is a prominent roboticist and professor of computer science at Stanford University, where he also directs the Stanford Robotics Laboratory. He is recognized for his pioneering contributions to robot motion planning, control, and human-robot interaction, including the development of the artificial potential field method and operational space formulation. Khatib has received numerous accolades, including the Engelberger Robotics Award for Education and election to the National Academy of Engineering. His current research interests encompass humanoid robotics, haptic interaction, and modeling human motor control.

Name: Michael I. Jordan
info: Michael Jeffrey Jordan, born on February 17, 1963, is a renowned American businessman and former professional basketball and baseball player, best known for his time with the Chicago Bulls in the NBA. Over a 15-season career, he won six NBA championships and is widely regarded as one of the greatest basketball players of all time, holding numerous records including the highest career scoring average in both regular season and playoffs. Jordan's accolades include six NBA Finals MVP awards and two inductions into the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame. Beyond his athletic achievements, he has made significant contributions to sports marketing, particularly through his association with Nike's Air Jordan brand. Currently, he is a minority owner of the Charlotte Hornets and has a net worth estimated at $3.8 billion as of 2025.

Name: Scott Delp
info: Scott L. Delp is an American academic serving as the James H. Clark Professor of Bioengineering and Mechanical Engineering at Stanford University, where he also founded the Department of Bioengineering. He directs the National Center for Simulation in Rehabilitation Research and the NIH Center for Physics-Based Simulations of Biological Structures. Delp is renowned for his contributions to biomechanics, particularly through the development of OpenSim, a software system that facilitates the creation and sharing of musculoskeletal models among researchers. His innovations include technologies for surgical navigation and microendoscopes for in vivo imaging, as well as pioneering work in optogenetics for treating neurological conditions. Delp has received numerous accolades, including election to the National Academy of Engineering and several prestigious awards in bioengineering and biomechanics.

Name: Surya Ganguli
info: Surya Ganguli is a university professor at Stanford University and a visiting research professor at Google, specializing in neural networks and deep learning. He leads the Neural Dynamics and Computation Lab, focusing on understanding how neuronal networks function across various scales to support cognitive processes. Ganguli has made significant contributions to theoretical neuroscience and has received numerous accolades, including the National Science Foundation CAREER Award and the Simons Investigator Award. He has an extensive publication record and is recognized for his impactful public speaking, having delivered over 200 talks since 2005.

Name: Eric Pop
info: Eric Pop is a Romanian-born American engineer and academic currently serving as the Pease-Ye Professor in the School of Engineering at Stanford University. He specializes in electrical engineering, with additional roles in applied physics and materials science and engineering. His research focuses on carbon nanotubes, phase-change memory, and nanotechnology, contributing significantly to the fields of electronics and energy. Notably, he received the Presidential Early Career Award for Scientists and Engineers in 2010 and is a fellow of the American Physical Society and the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers. Pop has been recognized as a Highly Cited Researcher and holds multiple patents, reflecting his impactful work in academia and industry.

Name: Gretchen C. Daily
info: Gretchen C. Daily is an American environmental scientist and tropical ecologist, known for her significant contributions to understanding humanity's relationship with nature and the valuation of ecosystem services. She is the co-founder and faculty director of the Natural Capital Project at Stanford University, which aims to integrate the values of nature into decision-making across various sectors globally. Daily holds the position of Bing Professor of Environmental Science in the Department of Biology at Stanford and directs the Center for Conservation Biology. Her notable works include the influential book "Nature's Services: Societal Dependence on Natural Ecosystems," which has shaped global conservation policies, and she has received numerous accolades, including election to the U.S. National Academy of Sciences. Daily continues to engage in research and advocacy for sustainable development and biodiversity conservation.

Name: David Lobell
info: David B. Lobell is an agricultural ecologist and the Gloria and Richard Kushel Director of the Center on Food Security and the Environment at Stanford University, where he also serves as a Professor of Earth System Science. His research focuses on the intersection of climate change and food security, particularly the impact of climate change on crop yields. Lobell was awarded a MacArthur "Genius" Fellowship in 2013 for his innovative use of data to address these issues. He has received several honors, including an Honorary Doctor of Science from Brown University in 2021 and the NAS Prize in Food and Agriculture Sciences in 2022.

Name: Vedika Khemani
info: Vedika Khemani is a theoretical physicist and Associate Professor at Stanford University, specializing in many-body quantum condensed matter physics and quantum information theory. She gained recognition for her research on non-equilibrium many-body quantum dynamics, particularly for identifying the Floquet time-crystal, a novel phase of matter that exhibits spontaneous breaking of time translation symmetry. Khemani has received several prestigious awards, including the 2024 Infosys Prize in Physical Sciences and the 2022 Breakthrough New Horizons in Physics Prize. She completed her undergraduate studies at Harvey Mudd College and earned her PhD from Princeton University, where she was advised by Shivaji Sondhi.

Name: Michael C. Frank
info: Michael Frank was a German American pioneer, newspaper editor, and politician, born on December 12, 1804, in Virgil, New York. He is best known as the first Mayor of Kenosha, Wisconsin, and is recognized as the father of Wisconsin public schools for his pivotal role in establishing free public education in the state. Frank co-founded the Southport Telegraph, which supported various social reform movements, and he was instrumental in drafting the public school code adopted by the Wisconsin legislature in 1849. He served in various public roles, including as a member of the Wisconsin State Assembly and as a Regent of the University of Wisconsin, before retiring from public life in Kenosha, where he passed away in 1894.

Name: Dan Jurafsky
info: Daniel Jurafsky is a professor of linguistics and computer science at Stanford University, recognized for his significant contributions to natural language processing, particularly in developing the first automatic system for semantic role labeling. He authored The Language of Food: A Linguist Reads the Menu, which was a finalist for the James Beard Award, and co-wrote a widely used textbook on speech and language processing. Jurafsky has received several honors, including a MacArthur Fellowship in 2002 and being named a fellow of the Linguistic Society of America in 2019. He holds a B.A. in linguistics and a Ph.D. in computer science from the University of California, Berkeley.

Name: David Eagleman
info: David Eagleman is an American neuroscientist, bestselling author, and science communicator, currently teaching neuroscience at Stanford University. He is recognized for his contributions to brain plasticity, time perception, synesthesia, and neurolaw, and has founded several neurotech startups, including BrainCheck and Neosensory. Eagleman is a Guggenheim Fellow and has authored works published in 32 languages, including the acclaimed book "Wednesday is Indigo Blue." He is also known for his television series "The Brain with David Eagleman" and the podcast "Inner Cosmos," which has received multiple accolades, including a nomination for the best science podcast at the 2024 iHeart Podcast Awards.

Name: Stephen Quake
info: Stephen Ronald Quake is an American physicist, inventor, and entrepreneur known for his pioneering work in microfluidics and genomics. He earned his B.S. in physics and M.S. in mathematics from Stanford University and a D.Phil. in theoretical physics from Oxford University. Quake has made significant contributions to single-cell analysis, non-invasive prenatal diagnostics, and single molecule DNA sequencing. He has received numerous awards, including the Lemelson–MIT Prize for Innovation and the NIH Director’s Pioneer Award, and is a member of several prestigious academies. Currently, he serves as the Lee Otterson Professor of Bioengineering and Applied Physics at Stanford University and was the Head of Science at the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative from 2022 to 2025.

Name: Christopher Potts
info: Christopher Potts is an American linguist and cognitive scientist, currently serving as Professor and Chair of the Department of Linguistics at Stanford University, with a courtesy appointment in the Computer Science Department. He is renowned for his contributions to formal semantics and pragmatics, particularly his multidimensional approach to expressivity and conventional implicature, as well as his development of probabilistic models of pragmatic inference. Potts earned his Ph.D. from the University of California, Santa Cruz, and has held faculty positions at the University of Massachusetts Amherst before joining Stanford in 2009. His work has garnered numerous accolades, including the ACL Test of Time Award in 2023 and multiple best paper awards at prestigious conferences.

Name: Crystal Mackall
info: Crystal L. Mackall is an American physician and immunologist, currently serving as the Ernest and Amelia Gallo Family Professor of Pediatrics and Medicine at Stanford University, where she is also the founding director of the Stanford Center for Cancer Cell Therapy. Her pioneering research focuses on cancer immunotherapies, particularly for pediatric cancers, and she has made significant contributions to the understanding of T cell biology and the development of CAR T cell therapies. Notable achievements include the development of CD19 and CD22 CAR T cell therapies, which have received Breakthrough Therapy Designation from the FDA, and her work on GD2-CAR therapy for diffuse midline gliomas. Mackall has received numerous awards for her contributions to cancer research, including the AACR-St. Baldrick's Foundation Award for Outstanding Achievement in Pediatric Cancer Research and recognition as a Fellow of the National Academy of Medicine.

Name: Robert Malenka
info: Robert C. Malenka is the Nancy Friend Pritzker Professor in Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences at Stanford University, where he also directs the Nancy Friend Pritzker Laboratory. His research focuses on synaptic plasticity and the impact of neural circuits on learning and memory, contributing significantly to the understanding of the neuronal basis of Alzheimer's disease. Malenka has published extensively, with notable works including a foundational paper in Neuron Magazine. He has received numerous accolades, including the Young Investigator Award from the Society for Neuroscience and the International Prize in Neuroscience. Currently, he is involved with various professional organizations and co-founded Circuit Therapeutics, Inc., which utilizes optogenetic technology for therapeutic applications.

Name: Edward I. Solomon
info: Edward Solomon was an English composer, conductor, orchestrator, and pianist born on July 25, 1855, in Lambeth, London. He is best known for his contributions to comic opera, particularly his works for the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company, including The Nautch Girl, which premiered in 1891 and enjoyed significant success. Solomon collaborated frequently with Henry Pottinger Stephens, producing popular operas such as Billee Taylor and Claude Duval. Despite a tumultuous personal life marked by a bigamous marriage to actress Lillian Russell, he left a lasting legacy in musical theatre before his untimely death from typhoid fever at the age of 39 on January 22, 1895.

Name: Ju Li
info: Ju Li is an American scientist and engineer, currently serving as the Battelle Energy Alliance Professor of Nuclear Science and Engineering and Materials Science and Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He earned his B.S. from the University of Science and Technology of China in 1994 and his Ph.D. from MIT in 2000. A highly cited expert in materials science, Li has made significant contributions to understanding atomic mechanisms in crystals and the development of advanced battery technologies. He has received numerous accolades, including being named a Fellow of the Materials Research Society and the American Physical Society, and has been recognized as a Clarivate Highly Cited Researcher.

Name: Dimitris Bertsimas
info: Dimitris Bertsimas is an American applied mathematician and a professor at the Sloan School of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). He holds a Diploma in Electrical Engineering from the National Technical University of Athens and earned his MS and PhD in Operations Research from MIT. Bertsimas is recognized for his contributions to optimization theory, stochastic systems, and their applications in various fields including finance and healthcare. He has authored over 250 scientific papers and five graduate-level textbooks, and has received numerous awards such as the INFORMS von Neumann Theory Prize and the Frederic W. Lanchester Prize. Currently, he serves as the Associate Dean of Business Analytics at MIT and is the founding director of the Masters of Business Analytics program.

Name: Dirk Englund
info: Dirk Robert Englund is a Professor of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, specializing in quantum photonics and optical computing. He earned his B.S. in physics from the California Institute of Technology, followed by an M.S. in electrical engineering and a Ph.D. in applied physics from Stanford University. His research encompasses a variety of topics in photonics, including quantum dot light emission, solid-state quantum memories, and optical accelerators for machine learning. Englund's contributions have led to the establishment of several spin-off companies focused on quantum technologies. He has received multiple awards for his work, including a Humboldt Professorship and the Optica Adolph Lomb Medal, and he is an Optica Fellow.

Name: Seth Lloyd
info: Seth Lloyd is an American quantum information scientist and professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Department of Mechanical Engineering. He has made significant contributions to quantum information science, including the development of designs for quantum computers, quantum error correction methods, and the HHL algorithm for solving linear equations. Lloyd is the author of the book "Programming the Universe," where he posits that the universe functions as a quantum computer. He has received several accolades, including being named a Fellow of the American Physical Society and the International Quantum Communication Award. Currently, he directs the Center for Extreme Quantum Information Theory at MIT.

Name: Brad Olsen
info: Brad Olsen is a prominent New Zealand economics commentator and the CEO of Infometrics, an economic consultancy based in Wellington. Born in January 1997 in Whangārei, he gained recognition as a "household name" following the COVID-19 pandemic. Olsen holds a double degree in economics and politics from Victoria University and has made significant contributions to youth advocacy and economic analysis, earning accolades such as the Queen's Young Leader Award in 2016 and Young Wellingtonian of the Year in 2020. He is actively involved in various leadership roles, including membership in the Asia New Zealand Foundation's Leadership Network and the Wellington Youth Council.

Name: Fikile Brushett
info: Fikile R. Brushett is an American chemical engineer and researcher specializing in electrochemical energy storage and sustainable energy technologies. He is currently the Chevron Professor of Chemical Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he has made significant contributions to the development of next-generation energy storage systems, particularly redox flow batteries. Brushett has received numerous accolades for his work, including the U.S. Department of Energy Secretary's Achievement Award and the NOBCChE Lloyd N. Ferguson Young Scientist Award. His research interests encompass electrochemical energy conversion, microfluidics, and catalyst synthesis, among others.

Name: Stuart Madnick
info: Stuart E. Madnick is an American computer scientist and professor of information technology at the MIT Sloan School of Management and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He has been a faculty member at MIT since 1972 and has held various leadership roles, including director of Cybersecurity at MIT Sloan. Madnick's research focuses on connectivity among distributed information systems, database technology, and software project management, and he has contributed significantly to industry projects such as IBM's VM/370 operating system. He is the author of over 250 publications, including textbooks and influential models in computer architecture, and has been involved in founding several high-tech firms.

Name: Richard D. Braatz
info: Richard D. Braatz is the Edwin R. Gilliland Professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, specializing in control theory and its applications in chemical, pharmaceutical, and materials systems. He has made significant contributions to robust optimal control, fault detection and diagnosis, and crystallization processes. Braatz has received numerous accolades, including the Hertz Foundation Thesis Prize, the Donald P. Eckman Award, and the Antonio Ruberti Young Researcher Prize, and he was elected to the National Academy of Engineering in 2019. He is a Fellow of several prestigious organizations, including the IEEE and the American Association for the Advancement of Science. Braatz holds a B.S. from Oregon State University and both an M.S. and Ph.D. from the California Institute of Technology.

Name: TOMASO POGGIO
info: Tomaso Armando Poggio, born on September 11, 1947, in Genoa, Italy, is the Eugene McDermott Professor in the Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences at MIT and an investigator at the McGovern Institute for Brain Research. He has made significant contributions to computational neuroscience, particularly in learning theory, computational vision, and the understanding of the visual system, collaborating with notable scientists such as David Marr and Francis Crick. Poggio's work has been influential in establishing the field of computational neuroscience, earning him numerous accolades including the Okawa Prize and the Swartz Prize for Theoretical and Computational Neuroscience. He is also recognized for mentoring leading figures in the field, including Christof Koch and Demis Hassabis. Currently, he directs the Center for Biological and Computational Learning and the Center for Brains, Minds, and Machines at MIT.

Name: Stephen L. Buchwald
info: Stephen L. Buchwald is an American chemist and the Camille Dreyfus Professor of Chemistry at MIT, born in 1955. He is renowned for his contributions to the development of the Buchwald-Hartwig amination and the discovery of the dialkylbiaryl phosphine ligand family, which facilitate this reaction and related transformations. Buchwald has coauthored over 435 academic publications and holds 47 patents. He has received numerous accolades, including the Wolf Prize in Chemistry in 2019 and the Arthur C. Cope Award in 2013, and he is a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and a member of the National Academy of Sciences. As of 2015, he also serves as an associate editor for the journal Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis.

Name: Max Tegmark
info: Max Erik Tegmark is a Swedish-American physicist and machine learning researcher, currently a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and president of the Future of Life Institute. He is renowned for his book "Life 3.0," which explores the implications of advancing artificial intelligence. His research spans cosmology and machine learning, contributing to significant advancements such as the use of baryon acoustic oscillations as a standard ruler and the mathematical universe hypothesis. Tegmark has received numerous accolades, including being elected a Fellow of the American Physical Society and awarded the Royal Swedish Academy of Engineering Science's Gold Medal. He is also involved in initiatives aimed at addressing existential risks associated with AI and has led projects like the AI-driven news aggregator Verity News.

Name: William A. Tisdale
info: William Tisdale, also known as Tisdall, was an English musician and composer active around the turn of the 17th century, primarily associated with the virginal school. Although little is known about his life, he is recognized for his contributions to keyboard music, with five pieces included in the Fitzwilliam Virginal Book and two in the John Bull Virginal Book. Notable works include "Mrs Katherin Tregians Paven," which reflects his connection to the Tregian family. Tisdale's music is characterized by rich chromaticism and has been preserved in anthologies edited by Howard Ferguson and Alan Brown.

Name: Daniel H. Rothman
info: Daniel H. Rothman is an American geophysicist and Professor of Geophysics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He has made significant contributions to statistical physics, enhancing the understanding of the natural environment's organization, with research spanning seismology, geobiology, fluid flow, and biogeochemistry. His recent work focuses on the Earth's carbon cycle and the dynamics of climate systems. Rothman holds an A.B. in applied mathematics from Brown University and a PhD in geophysics from Stanford University. He is a Fellow of the American Physical Society and the American Geophysical Union, and received the 2016 Levi L. Conant Prize from the American Mathematical Society. Additionally, he co-founded MIT's Lorenz Center, which focuses on climate research, and co-authored the book "Lattice-Gas Cellular Automata: Simple Models of Complex Hydrodynamics."

Name: Kaiming He
info: Kaiming He is a Chinese computer scientist specializing in computer vision and deep learning. He is currently an associate professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a Distinguished Scientist at Google DeepMind. He is recognized for co-developing the residual neural network (ResNet) and his influential paper "Deep Residual Learning for Image Recognition," which became the most cited research paper in its field between 2016 and 2021. He has received several prestigious awards, including the ICCV Marr Prize in 2017 and the CVPR best paper awards in 2009 and 2016, and was honored with the 2023 Future Science Prize for his contributions to artificial intelligence.

Name: Rosalind Picard
info: Rosalind Wright Picard is an American scholar and inventor, currently serving as the Grover M. Hermann Professor of Health Sciences and Technology at MIT and directing the Affective Computing Research Group at the MIT Media Lab. She is recognized as a pioneer in the field of affective computing, having authored the foundational book on the subject in 1997, which explores the integration of emotional intelligence in machines. Picard's notable contributions include advancements in image and video analysis, wearable computing, and the development of technologies that enhance emotional recognition in humans and machines. Her work has earned her numerous accolades, including election to the National Academy of Engineering and the National Academy of Inventors, as well as being named a Fellow of the IEEE and ACM. She co-founded Affectiva and Empatica, startups focused on emotion-sensing technologies, and continues to influence various fields through her research and innovations.

Name: Constantinos Daskalakis
info: Constantinos Daskalakis is a Greek theoretical computer scientist and a professor at MIT's Electrical Engineering and Computer Science department, as well as a member of the MIT Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory. His research focuses on the theory of computation, particularly its intersections with game theory, economics, and machine learning, where he has made significant contributions to the computational complexity of Nash equilibria and multi-item auctions. Daskalakis has received several prestigious awards, including the Rolf Nevanlinna Prize and the Grace Murray Hopper Award in 2018, and he is a co-founder and chief scientist of the Archimedes AI research center. He was also named an ACM Fellow in 2022 for his fundamental contributions to algorithmic game theory and theoretical machine learning.

Name: Carlo Ratti
info: Carlo Ratti, born in 1971 in Turin, Italy, is an influential architect, engineer, inventor, and author, currently serving as a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he directs the MIT Senseable City Lab. He is a founding partner of CRA-Carlo Ratti Associati, an international design firm, and holds distinguished academic positions at the Politecnico di Milano and TTPU Tashkent. Ratti's notable contributions include pioneering projects like The Copenhagen Wheel and Trash Track, which explore the intersection of digital technology and urban environments, and he has been recognized as one of the "50 most influential designers in America." His work has garnered numerous accolades, and in December 2023, he was appointed curator of the 19th Venice Biennale of Architecture, set to open in 2025.

Name: Heather J. Kulik
info: Heather J. Kulik is an American computational materials scientist and engineer, currently serving as the Lammot Du Pont Professor of Chemical Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. She specializes in the computational design of new materials and the application of artificial intelligence to predict material properties. Kulik's notable contributions include the introduction of a Hubbard U term to density functional theory, enhancing the study of transition metal complexes. Her research has earned her several prestigious awards, including the DARPA Young Faculty Award and the National Science Foundation CAREER Award. She joined MIT's faculty in 2013 and continues to advance the field of computational modeling and materials discovery.

Name: Evelyn N Wang
info: Evelyn Ning-Yi Wang is a mechanical engineer and the Vice President for Energy and Climate at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). She is the Ford Professor of Mechanical Engineering and director of the Device Research Laboratory, focusing on heat transfer, ultrahydrophobicity, solar energy, and nanostructures. Wang is renowned for her innovative research on solar-powered devices that extract drinkable water from the atmosphere, which was recognized as one of the "Top 10 Emerging Technologies of 2017" by Scientific American. She has received numerous accolades, including the Young Faculty Award from DARPA, the ASME Bergles-Rohsenow Young Investigator Award, and election to the National Academy of Engineering in 2025. Wang holds a bachelor's degree from MIT and a doctorate from Stanford University, and she previously served as director of the Advanced Research Projects Agency-Energy in the Biden administration.

Name: Evelina (Ev) Fedorenko
info: Evelina G. Fedorenko is a Russian-born American cognitive neuroscientist, currently a tenured professor and laboratory head in the Brain and Cognitive Sciences department at MIT. She specializes in the human language system, aiming to map brain regions associated with language and study cognitive processes in both healthy individuals and those with brain disorders. Fedorenko employs various methodologies, including fMRI and intracranial recordings, and has conducted notable research on polyglots. She received the Pathway to Independence Award in 2007 and has contributed to prominent publications such as The New Yorker and BBC World Service.

Name: Brian Williams
info: Brian Douglas Williams is an American journalist and television news anchor, born on May 5, 1959. He began his career in broadcasting in 1981 and joined NBC News in 1993, eventually becoming the anchor and managing editor of NBC Nightly News in 2004. Williams is known for his coverage of significant events, particularly Hurricane Katrina, which earned NBC Nightly News multiple prestigious awards, including a Peabody Award. However, his career faced controversy in 2015 when he was suspended for misrepresenting events during the Iraq War, leading to his removal from NBC Nightly News. After a stint as the host of MSNBC's The 11th Hour, he announced his departure from NBC News in 2021 and is set to host Election Night coverage for Amazon in 2024.

Name: John Williams
info: John Towner Williams, born on February 8, 1932, is a renowned American composer and conductor celebrated for his iconic film scores. Over his extensive seven-decade career, he has crafted music for numerous classic films, particularly through collaborations with directors George Lucas and Steven Spielberg, resulting in memorable scores for franchises such as Star Wars and Indiana Jones. Williams has received a multitude of accolades, including 26 Grammy Awards and five Academy Awards, making him the second-most nominated individual in Academy Award history. He has also composed classical works and served as the principal conductor of the Boston Pops. Currently, he continues to influence the film music landscape and was honored with an honorary knighthood in 2022 for his contributions to film music.

Name: Neville Hogan
info: Neville Hogan is an Irish-American engineer and the Sun Jae Professor of Mechanical Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. His interdisciplinary research spans motor neuroscience, rehabilitation engineering, and robotics, with a particular emphasis on developing robots that can safely assist humans in physical therapy.
