Hogan's pioneering work in creating gentle robots for rehabilitating frail patients has significant clinical implications. He has received numerous accolades, including the Rufus Oldenburger Medal and the Pioneer in Robotics and Automation Award from the IEEE Robotics and Automation Society, and he holds honorary doctorates from Delft University of Technology and Dublin Institute of Technology.

Name: Klaus-Jürgen Bathe
info: Klaus-Jürgen Bathe is a prominent civil engineer and professor of mechanical engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, known for his pioneering work in computational mechanics and finite element analysis. He founded ADINA R&D, where he developed influential software that has significantly advanced the field. Bathe's key contributions include the formulation of plate and shell finite elements, large deformation analysis, and innovative solution techniques for eigenvalue and contact problems. He has authored several important texts, including "Finite Element Procedures," and has received numerous honorary doctorates and accolades for his work, including recognition as a Highly Cited Author in Engineering. Currently, he continues to contribute to academia and industry while serving as an editor for various scientific journals.

Name: Dina Katabi
info: Dina Katabi is the Andrew and Erna Viterbi Professor of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science at MIT and the director of the MIT Wireless Center. She has made significant contributions to the fields of wireless networking, machine learning, and health diagnostics, particularly through her innovative use of radio frequency signals to monitor vital health metrics without the need for wearable sensors. Katabi's notable works include advancements in network congestion control and the development of AI systems for diagnosing Parkinson's disease. She has received numerous accolades, including the Grace Murray Hopper Award, a MacArthur Fellowship, and election to the National Academy of Engineering and the National Academy of Sciences. As of 2024, she continues her research at MIT, focusing on AI-powered health monitoring technologies.

Name: Gareth McKinley
info: Gareth Huw McKinley is a Professor of Teaching Innovation in the Department of Mechanical Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). He completed his education at the University of Cambridge and earned his PhD at MIT, focusing on the rheology of complex fluids such as surfactants, gels, and polymers. His notable contributions include research in non-Newtonian fluid dynamics and microfluidics, and he served as director of MIT's polymer science program from 2004 to 2009. McKinley has received several awards, including the Bingham Medal and the Gold Medal of the British Society of Rheology, and he was elected to the National Academy of Engineering in 2019. He is also a co-founder of Cambridge Polymer Group, which specializes in materials consulting and instrumentation.

Name: Luigi Zingales
info: Luigi Zingales is an Italian finance professor at the University of Chicago Booth School of Business, where he holds the title of Robert C. McCormack Distinguished Service Professor of Entrepreneurship and Finance. He earned his bachelor's degree in economics from Bocconi University and a Ph.D. from MIT, focusing on corporate control. Zingales is known for his influential works, including "Saving Capitalism from the Capitalists" and "A Capitalism for the People," which address issues of relationship capitalism and the need for competitive reinvigoration in American markets. He has received notable recognition, including the Germán Bernácer Prize and inclusion in Foreign Policy's Top 100 Global Thinkers list. Zingales actively engages in public discourse on economic regulation and has been involved in various initiatives, including co-hosting the podcast "Capitalisn't."

Name: Stuart Rowan
info: Stuart J. Rowan is a Scottish chemist born in 1969, known for his significant contributions to the field of macromolecular science and engineering. He completed his Bachelor of Science at the University of Glasgow and earned his doctorate in 1995. Rowan has held academic positions at Case Western Reserve University and currently serves as the Barry L. MacLean Professor for Molecular Engineering Innovation and Enterprise at The University of Chicago, where he is also affiliated with Argonne National Laboratory. His notable achievements include receiving multiple National Science Foundation awards, a fellowship from the Royal Society of Chemistry, and being elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in 2024. Rowan is also recognized for his editorial role in ACS Macro Letters, where he has served as editor in chief since 2018.

Name: James Heckman
info: James Joseph Heckman is an American economist and Nobel laureate, currently serving as the Henry Schultz Distinguished Service Professor in Economics at the University of Chicago. He is renowned for his pioneering contributions to econometrics and microeconomics, particularly in addressing selection bias through the Heckman correction, which earned him the Nobel Prize in Economic Sciences in 2000. Heckman's extensive research focuses on labor economics and the effectiveness of early childhood education programs, and he has published over 300 articles and several influential books. He has received numerous accolades, including the John Bates Clark Medal and the Jacob Mincer Award for Lifetime Achievement in Labor Economics, and he is a member of several prestigious academic societies.

Name: Paul Alivisatos
info: Armand Paul Alivisatos is a Greek-American chemist born on November 12, 1959, who currently serves as the 14th president of the University of Chicago. His research primarily focuses on nanomaterials, particularly in the synthesis and application of semiconductor nanocrystals for biomedical and renewable energy uses. Notable contributions include pioneering techniques for creating complex-shaped nanocrystals and developing quantum dots, which have significant implications in bioimaging and solar energy technologies. Alivisatos has received numerous accolades, including an Alfred P. Sloan Foundation fellowship, and has held key administrative roles at the University of California, Berkeley, and Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. He is recognized as a leading figure in nanotechnology and continues to influence the field through his research and leadership.

Name: Gregory A. Voth
info: Gregory A. Voth is a theoretical chemist and the Haig P. Papazian Distinguished Service Professor of Chemistry at the University of Chicago, where he also holds positions at the James Franck Institute and the Institute for Biophysical Dynamics. He earned his bachelor's degree from the University of Kansas and a Ph.D. in theoretical chemistry from the California Institute of Technology. Voth is renowned for developing the multiscale coarse-graining method, which simplifies molecular-scale entities while retaining essential interaction information, and for his research on charge transport in biomolecules and complex materials. He has authored over 650 peer-reviewed articles and received numerous awards, including the Procter and Gamble Award and the Guggenheim Fellowship. As of 2025, he continues to contribute significantly to the field of theoretical chemistry through his research and mentorship.

Name: Laura Gagliardi
info: Laura Gagliardi is an Italian theoretical and computational chemist currently serving as the Richard and Kathy Leventhal Professor of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering at the University of Chicago. She is recognized for her significant contributions to the development of electronic structure methods to analyze complex chemical systems. Gagliardi earned her Master of Science and PhD from the University of Bologna and has held academic positions at the University of Palermo, University of Geneva, and University of Minnesota, where she also directed several research centers. Her accolades include the Pauling Medal Award, election to the National Academy of Sciences, and the Faraday Lectureship Prize, among others. She is also the Editor-in-Chief of the Journal of Chemical Theory and Computation.

Name: Marc G. Berman
info: Marc Berman is an American lawyer and politician serving as a member of the California State Assembly since 2016, representing the 23rd Assembly District. He is a Democrat with a background in political science and law, having earned his degrees from Georgetown University and USC Gould School of Law. Berman has made notable contributions in housing policy and digital media legislation, including a law to regulate the distribution of manipulated political content and changes to California's recall law. He previously served on the Palo Alto City Council and is a member of the California Legislative Progressive Caucus.

Name: Giulia Galli
info: Giulia Galli is a prominent condensed-matter physicist serving as the Liew Family Professor of Electronic Structure and Simulations at the Pritzker School of Molecular Engineering and the department of chemistry at the University of Chicago, as well as a senior scientist at Argonne National Laboratory. She is recognized for her pioneering work in computational condensed-matter physics, particularly in first principles simulations of materials, liquids, and excited state phenomena relevant to energy applications and water properties. Galli has received numerous accolades, including election to the National Academy of Sciences and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and she has been awarded the Aneesur Rahman Prize for Computational Physics. Currently, she directs the Midwest Integrated Center for Computational Materials, which focuses on developing open-source software and methodologies for simulating functional materials.

Name: Guangbin Dong
info: Guangbin Dong is an accomplished organic chemist currently serving as the Weldon G. Brown Professor at the University of Chicago. His research focuses on organic synthesis, catalysis, organometallics, medicinal chemistry, and material science, with notable contributions in carbon-carbon activation, palladium/norbornene catalysis, and the synthesis of complex bioactive natural products. Dong has developed innovative methodologies for enantioselective synthesis and has synthesized several natural products with significant anticancer activity. He has received numerous awards, including the Mukaiyama Award and the Friedrich Wilhelm Bessel Research Award, and has been recognized as a Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

Name: Luc Anselin
info: Luc E. Anselin is a prominent figure in the field of spatial econometrics and serves as the Stein-Freiler Distinguished Service Professor of Sociology at the University of Chicago. He previously held the position of Regents' Professor and Director of the School of Geographical Sciences and Urban Planning at Arizona State University, where he founded the GeoDa Center for Geospatial Analysis and Computation. Anselin is recognized for his significant contributions to spatial methodologies and software tools, including the development of GeoDa and PySAL, which have advanced the discipline of spatial econometrics. His influential book, Spatial Econometrics: Methods and Models, has been widely cited, and he has received numerous accolades, including election to the National Academy of Sciences and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.

Name: John Mearsheimer
info: John Joseph Mearsheimer, born on December 14, 1947, is an influential American political scientist and international relations scholar, currently serving as the R. Wendell Harrison Distinguished Service Professor at the University of Chicago. He is renowned for his development of the neorealist theory of offensive realism, particularly articulated in his seminal work, The Tragedy of Great Power Politics, where he argues that great powers are driven by the desire for regional hegemony. Mearsheimer's notable contributions also include The Israel Lobby and U.S. Foreign Policy, which critiques the influence of the Israel lobby on American foreign policy, and The Great Delusion: Liberal Dreams and International Realities, where he critiques the liberal international order. He has received several prestigious awards, including the James Madison Award from the American Political Science Association, and is recognized as one of the most cited scholars in the field of international relations.

Name: Michael Greenstone
info: Michael Greenstone is an American economist and the Milton Friedman Distinguished Service Professor in Economics at the Harris School of Public Policy at the University of Chicago. He is the director of the Energy Policy Institute at Chicago and the Becker Friedman Institute, and co-chair of the Energy and Environment sector at J-PAL. Greenstone's research focuses on the intersection of development and environmental economics, particularly the economic impacts of air pollution and climate change. He has received recognition for his contributions, including serving as chief economist on the Council of Economic Advisors during the Obama administration. Currently, he is actively involved in various research initiatives and serves on editorial boards for prominent economic journals.

Name: Marianne Bertrand
info: Marianne Bertrand is a Belgian economist and the Chris P. Dialynas Distinguished Service Professor of Economics at the University of Chicago's Booth School of Business. Renowned for her research in labor economics, corporate governance, and development economics, she has made significant contributions to understanding racial and gender discrimination in the labor market. Notable works include her influential studies on the impact of implicit discrimination and the effects of antitakeover legislation on wage setting. Bertrand has received prestigious awards such as the Elaine Bennett Research Prize and the Sherwin Rosen Prize, and she is actively involved with several research organizations, including the National Bureau of Economic Research and the IZA Institute of Labor Economics.

Name: Juan J. de Pablo
info: Juan Pablo is a common name in Spanish-speaking cultures, equivalent to "John Paul" in English. Notable individuals with this name span various fields, including sports, politics, and literature. Among them are Juan Pablo Montoya, a prominent race car driver, and Juan Pablo Vizcardo y Guzmán, a significant 18th-century Peruvian writer known for his contributions to Latin American independence. The name is associated with numerous athletes, particularly in football, highlighting its prevalence in sports culture.

Name: Ufuk Akcigit
info: Ufuk Akcigit is a Turkish economist born on May 23, 1980, currently serving as the Arnold C. Harberger Professor of Economics at the University of Chicago. His research focuses on economic growth and development, particularly the relationship between innovation and policy, employing a blend of micro and macroeconomic approaches. Akcigit has made significant contributions to the understanding of creative destruction, firm dynamics, and income inequality, and has published extensively in leading economic journals. He has received numerous accolades, including the Econometric Society Fellow and the John Simon Guggenheim Fellow, and has played a key role in initiatives such as the World Development Report 2024. In addition to his academic responsibilities, he leads the Akcigit Research Team, which investigates the impact of talent allocation and industrial policies on economic growth.

Name: Ernst Lengyel
info: Ernst Robert Lengyel is an American gynecologic oncologist and the Arthur L. and Lee G. Herbst Professor of Obstetrics and Gynecology at the University of Chicago. He directs the Ovarian Cancer Research Laboratory, focusing on ovarian cancer metastasis and the development of new treatments, including innovative research on the role of the fallopian tube in ovarian cancer. Lengyel has made significant contributions to the field, including the first high-throughput screening drug-discovery platform for ovarian cancer and novel therapeutic strategies to inhibit cancer spread. He has received several accolades, including the Burroughs Wellcome Fund Clinical Scientist Award and a grant from the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative, and he was elected a Member of the National Academy of Medicine for his achievements.

Name: Rick Stevens
info: Rick Stevens is a professor of computer science at the University of Chicago and serves as the associate laboratory director for Computing, Environment and Life Sciences at Argonne National Laboratory. He has made significant contributions to high-performance computing and has held various leadership roles at Argonne, including director of the High-Performance Computing and Communications Program. Stevens has been recognized as a Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, and the Association for Computing Machinery. His academic background includes degrees in applied mathematics and philosophy, as well as advanced studies in applied mathematics, computer science, and physics.

Name: Steven D. Levitt
info: Steven David Levitt is an American economist known for his influential work in the field of crime economics and as the co-author of the best-selling book Freakonomics. He is a professor emeritus at the University of Chicago, where he also serves as the William B. Ogden Distinguished Service Professor and director of the Gary Becker Milton Friedman Institute for Research in Economics. Levitt received the John Bates Clark Medal in 2003 for his significant contributions to economics, particularly his controversial research linking legalized abortion to crime reduction. He has published over 60 academic papers and co-founded TGG Group, a consulting firm, in 2009. Levitt was recognized as one of Time magazine's "100 People Who Shape Our World" in 2006.

Name: Ayelet Fishbach
info: Ayelet Fishbach is the Eric J. Gleacher Distinguished Service Professor of Behavioral Science and Marketing at the University of Chicago Booth School of Business. She specializes in social psychology, management, and consumer behavior, and has served as president of the Society for the Science of Motivation and the International Social Cognition Network. Fishbach has contributed significantly to her field through her roles as associate editor for the Journal of Personality and Social Psychology and Psychological Science. Her notable works include "Get It Done: Surprising Lessons from the Science of Motivation" and "Goal Systems Theory: Psychological Processes and Applications."

Name: Jean Decety
info: Jean Decety is an American–French neuroscientist known for his work in developmental, affective, and social neuroscience. His research investigates the psychological and neurobiological mechanisms of social cognition, including empathy, moral reasoning, and prosocial behavior. He is the Irving B. Harris Distinguished Service Professor at the University of Chicago, where he directs the Social Cognitive Neuroscience Laboratory and the Child NeuroSuite. Decety has contributed significantly to the understanding of empathy's role in moral behavior and its complex relationship with justice, and he has published extensively in this field. In 2022, he was elected to the Academia Europaea, recognizing his influential contributions to neuroscience.

Name: Margaret Gardel
info: Margaret Lise Gardel is an American biophysicist and the Horace B. Horton Professor in the Department of Physics at the University of Chicago. She earned her bachelor's degree in physics and mathematics from Brown University and completed her PhD at Harvard University, where she focused on the deformation of actin under mechanical stress. Gardel has made significant contributions to the understanding of cellular materials and their physical behaviors, receiving numerous accolades including the NIH Director's Pioneer Award and the Raymond and Beverly Sackler International Prize in Biophysics. She currently serves as the Lead Editor of PRX Life, a journal dedicated to the physics of living systems.

Name: Diyi Yang
info: Diyi Yang is a Chinese computer scientist and assistant professor of computer science at Stanford University, where she leads the Social and Language Technologies Lab. Her research integrates linguistics and social sciences with machine learning to develop socially-aware language technologies, focusing on user-centered text generation and natural language processing for limited data contexts. Yang earned her Bachelor of Science degree from Shanghai Jiao Tong University and both her M.S. and Ph.D. from Carnegie Mellon University. She has received several accolades, including being named a Sloan Research Fellow, Kavli Fellow, and Microsoft Research Faculty Fellow, and was recognized in Forbes 30 Under 30 for Science in 2021.

Name: Christopher Ré
info: Christopher Ré is an American computer scientist and a full professor at Stanford University. He specializes in big data analysis and was awarded a MacArthur Fellowship in 2015. Ré co-founded Lattice.io, a data mining and machine learning company acquired by Apple in 2017, and has been involved in founding several academic projects that led to startups such as Together AI and Snorkel.

Name: Mark Gerstein
info: Mark Bender Gerstein is an American scientist specializing in bioinformatics and data science, currently serving as the Albert L. Williams Professor of Biomedical Informatics and holding multiple professorships at Yale University. He co-directs the Yale Computational Biology and Bioinformatics program and the Yale Center for Biomedical Data Science. Gerstein's research focuses on applying computational methods to molecular biology, with significant contributions including the development of various databases and tools for genome analysis and molecular simulations. He has received numerous awards, including a W. M. Keck Foundation Distinguished Young Scholars award and recognition as a Fellow of the AAAS and the International Society for Computational Biology. His work is widely published and highly cited, reflecting his influence in the fields of genomics and data science.

Name: Luciano Floridi
info: Luciano Floridi is an Italian and British philosopher, currently serving as the John K. Castle Professor in the Practice of Cognitive Science and Founding Director of the Digital Ethics Center at Yale University. He is also a Professor of Sociology of Culture and Communication at the University of Bologna and an adjunct professor at American University in Washington D.C. Floridi is renowned for his contributions to the philosophy of information and information ethics, earning numerous accolades including the Knight of the Grand Cross of the Order of Merit from Italy. His influential works include the formulation of the Philosophy of Information, which explores the nature and moral implications of information. Prior to his current roles, he held various academic positions, including at the University of Oxford and the University of Hertfordshire.

Name: Karen C. Seto
info: Karen Seto is a prominent geographer and urbanisation scientist, currently serving as the Frederick C. Hixon Professor of Geography and Urbanisation Science at Yale University. She is recognized for her significant contributions to understanding urbanisation and its implications for global sustainability, particularly through her leadership roles in the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, where she co-led the urban mitigation chapters of both the 5th and 6th Assessment Reports. Seto's research integrates satellite imagery with socioeconomic data to analyze urban land expansion and its environmental impacts, with a focus on regions such as China and Nepal. Her work has earned her numerous accolades, including election to the U.S. National Academy of Sciences and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and she has been recognized as a highly cited researcher multiple times.

Name: William L. Jorgensen
info: William L. Jorgensen is a Sterling Professor of Chemistry at Yale University, renowned for his contributions to computational chemistry. He developed several influential water models (TIP3P, TIP4P, TIP5P) and the OPLS force field, and he advanced free-energy perturbation theory for modeling reactions in solution and drug design. Jorgensen earned his bachelor's degree from Princeton and his PhD from Harvard, later serving on the faculty at Purdue University before joining Yale in 1990. His research focuses on the calculation of free energy in reactions, with applications in protein-ligand binding and drug design, including recent work on inhibitors for the SARS-CoV-2 virus. He has received numerous accolades, including election to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and the National Academy of Sciences, and has been honored with several prestigious awards in his field.

Name: Menachem Elimelech
info: Menachem Elimelech is the Nancy and Clint Carlson Professor at Rice University, holding joint appointments in the Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering and the Department of Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering. Previously, he was the Sterling Professor of Chemical and Environmental Engineering at Yale University, where he founded the Environmental Engineering program. Elimelech is renowned for his pioneering research in membrane processes for desalination and water reuse, as well as advancements in brine and wastewater management technologies. He has authored over 590 refereed journal publications and has received numerous accolades, including election to multiple national and international engineering academies. His influential works include significant articles in leading journals that have shaped the fields of water purification and desalination.

Name: Laurie Santos
info: Laurie Renee Santos is an American cognitive scientist and professor of psychology at Yale University, where she directs the Comparative Cognition Laboratory and the Canine Cognition Lab. She is known for her research on the evolutionary origins of the human mind, particularly through comparisons with non-human animals. Santos gained widespread recognition for her course "Psychology and the Good Life," which became Yale's most popular course and was later offered online as "The Science of Well-Being." She hosts the podcast "The Happiness Lab," which explores scientific insights into happiness and well-being. Santos has received numerous accolades, including being named one of Popular Science's "Brilliant Ten" and a Genius Award from the Liberty Science Center, and she continues to contribute to the field through her research and public engagement.

Name: Mark Bradford
info: Mark Bradford is an American visual artist born on November 20, 1961, in South Los Angeles, where he continues to live and work. He studied at the California Institute of the Arts, earning his BFA in 1995 and MFA in 1997. Bradford is renowned for his collaged paintings that incorporate layers of paper and various materials, often addressing themes of masculinity, race, and social issues. His notable works include "Scorched Earth," "Black Wall Street," and "150 Portrait Tone," and he represented the U.S. at the 2017 Venice Biennale. Recognized for his significant contributions to contemporary art, he was named one of Time Magazine's 100 Most Influential People in 2021 and currently holds a prominent position in the art community.

Name: Jonathon Howard
info: Jonathon (Joe) Howard is a prominent biophysicist and cell biologist, currently serving as the Eugene Higgins Professor of Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry and a professor of physics at Yale University. His research primarily focuses on microtubules, motor proteins, and the mechanics of cell shape and motion. Howard has made significant contributions to the understanding of hair cells and motor proteins, including the development of single-molecule assays and the elucidation of kinesin's movement along microtubules. He has authored the influential monograph "Mechanics of Motor Proteins and the Cytoskeleton," which has garnered widespread recognition. Throughout his career, he has received numerous awards, including election to the Connecticut Academy of Science and Engineering and the title of Fellow of the Biophysical Society.

Name: Jung Han
info: Jung Han is an accomplished academic affiliated with Yale University in New Haven, Connecticut. He was recognized as a Fellow of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) in 2013 for his significant contributions to epitaxial technologies related to wide bandgap semiconductor materials and devices. His work has advanced the field of semiconductor technology, impacting various applications in electronics and optoelectronics.

Name: Michelle L. Bell
info: Michelle Bell is an American singer-songwriter and record producer known for her collaborations with prominent artists in the music industry. She gained recognition for her work with Sean Combs, writing and producing tracks for Jennifer Lopez, which led to further collaborations with artists such as Britney Spears, Mary J. Blige, and Paulina Rubio. Notable contributions include several tracks on Britney Spears' album "In the Zone" and the song "(I've Just Begun) Having My Fun," which received critical acclaim. Bell has also formed a music production duo with Peter Wade Keusch, working on projects for various artists. She currently resides in New York City.

Name: Dirk Bergemann
info: Dirk Bergemann is the Douglass & Marion Campbell Professor of Economics and Computer Science at Yale University. He earned his Vordiplom in economics from Goethe University Frankfurt and both his M.A. and Ph.D. from the University of Pennsylvania. His research focuses on game theory, contract theory, and mechanism design, with significant contributions including the development of robust mechanism design alongside Stephen Morris, which challenged traditional assumptions in the field. Bergemann has published extensively in leading journals and has received support from various prestigious grants. He is a fellow of the European Economic Association and serves as a foreign editor for the Review of Economic Studies and as an associate editor for several other academic publications.

Name: Nicholas A. Christakis
info: Nicholas A. Christakis is a Greek American sociologist and physician renowned for his research on social networks and their impact on human welfare, including health and behavior. He is the Sterling Professor of Social and Natural Science at Yale University, where he also directs the Human Nature Lab and co-directs the Yale Institute for Network Science. Christakis has authored or edited six books and over 200 peer-reviewed articles, contributing significantly to the fields of network science and biosocial science. He has received numerous accolades, including election to the National Academy of Sciences in 2024 and recognition as one of Time magazine's 100 most influential people in 2009. His current research focuses on social contagion and the dynamics of health behaviors within social networks.

Name: Bryan Kelly
info: Bryan George Kelly, born on January 3, 1934, is an English composer, conductor, and pianist known for his diverse contributions to orchestral and choral music. He studied at the Royal College of Music and has taught at prestigious institutions including the Royal Scottish Academy of Music and the Royal College of Music, with teaching stints in several countries. His notable works include the Symphony (1983), the choral piece St. Francis of Assisi (1981), and various lighter orchestral compositions such as the Cuban Suite and New Orleans Suite. Kelly's music has been recorded on multiple CDs, showcasing his extensive repertoire, and he continues to be recognized for his significant impact on contemporary classical music.

Name: Harlan Krumholz
info: Harlan M. Krumholz, MD, SM is a prominent American cardiologist and the Harold H. Hines, Jr. Professor of Medicine at Yale School of Medicine, where he has been a faculty member since 1992. He is a pioneer in outcomes research, focusing on improving healthcare quality and efficiency, reducing disparities, and promoting patient-centered care. Krumholz has published over 1500 articles and has significantly influenced cardiovascular care through initiatives like the Door-to-Balloon Alliance, which improved treatment times for heart attack patients. He is also a strong advocate for open science and has co-founded the Yale Open Data Access Project, facilitating the sharing of clinical trial data. Currently, he continues to lead research efforts at the Yale New Haven Hospital Center for Outcomes Research and Evaluation.

Name: Aaron M. Dollar
info: Aaron Dollar is a professor of Mechanical Engineering & Materials Science and Computer Science at Yale University, where he leads the GRAB Lab. His research specializes in the analysis, design, and control of compliant mechanisms. In 2010, he was honored as an innovator by being named to the MIT Technology Review's TR35 list. He holds a Ph.D. and M.S. in Engineering Science from Harvard University and a B.S. in Mechanical Engineering from the University of Massachusetts at Amherst.

Name: Craig Crews
info: Craig M. Crews is an American scientist at Yale University, where he holds the John C. Malone Professorship in Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology, along with joint appointments in Chemistry and Pharmacology. He is renowned for his pioneering work in chemical biology, particularly in the development of proteolysis-targeting chimeras (PROTACs), which facilitate targeted protein degradation by inducing the proximity of proteins to the cellular degradation machinery. Crews has founded two biotechnology companies, including Arvinas, which focuses on developing PROTAC-based therapies for cancer and other diseases. His notable contributions have earned him several awards, including the Scheele Prize and the Passano Award, and he was recently honored with the 2024 Kimberly Prize in Biochemistry and Molecular Genetics.

Name: Akiko Iwasaki
info: Akiko Iwasaki is a Sterling Professor of Immunobiology and Molecular, Cellular and Developmental Biology at Yale University and a principal investigator at the Howard Hughes Medical Institute. Her research focuses on innate immunity, autophagy, and the immune responses to various viral infections, including influenza, herpes simplex virus, and COVID-19. Notable contributions include her pioneering work on DNA vaccines and the development of a two-stage vaccination strategy for cervical cancer prevention. Iwasaki has received numerous accolades, including election to the National Academy of Sciences in 2018 and the Else Kröner-Fresenius Prize for Medical Research in 2023. She currently serves as the president of the American Association of Immunologists for the 2023–2024 term.

Name: Jeffrey C. Alexander
info: Jeffrey Charles Alexander is an influential American sociologist born in 1947, recognized for his significant contributions to social theory, particularly in cultural sociology. He challenged traditional views that relegated culture to a mere reflection of economic and political forces, instead positioning culture as a central element in sociological analysis. His development of the Strong Program in the 1990s established culture as an independent force shaping social actions and institutions, with concepts like cultural trauma emerging from his work. Alexander has authored or co-authored ten books and has received numerous accolades, including honorary doctorates from several universities and prestigious awards such as the Clifford Geertz Award and the Mary Douglas Prize. He is currently the Lillian Chavenson Saden Professor of Sociology at Yale University and co-director of the Center for Cultural Sociology.

Name: Rohini Pande
info: Rohini Pande is an economist currently serving as the Henry J. Heinz II Professor of Economics and Director of the Economic Growth Center at Yale University. Previously, she held the Rafik Hariri Professorship of International Political Economy at Harvard Kennedy School and co-directed the Evidence for Policy Design research program. Pande's research primarily focuses on the economic implications of governance, women's empowerment, and the role of public policy in developing countries, particularly in India. Her notable contributions include influential works on the impact of rural banks and female leadership on social outcomes, earning her the Infosys Prize in Social Sciences in 2022. She is actively involved in various academic boards and research organizations, including the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab and the National Bureau of Economic Research.

Name: Steven M. Girvin
info: Steven Mark Girvin is an American physicist and Sterling Professor at Yale University, where he also holds a position in applied physics. He is renowned for his theoretical contributions to quantum many-body systems, particularly the fractional quantum Hall effect, and for co-developing circuit quantum electrodynamics, a leading architecture for quantum computing with superconducting qubits. Girvin has co-edited significant works, including The Quantum Hall Effect, and authored the textbook Modern Condensed Matter Physics. He has received numerous accolades, including the Oliver E. Buckley Condensed Matter Prize and election to the National Academy of Sciences. In 2020, he became the founding director of the Co-design Center for Quantum Advantage at Brookhaven National Laboratory.

Name: David MacMillan
info: David Neil Stirling Macmillan was a British historian born on 9 October 1925 in Airdrie, Scotland. He obtained a master's degree from the University of Glasgow in 1949 and a PhD from the University of Sydney in 1965. Macmillan taught at the University of Sydney and later at Trent University in Ontario, Canada, where he served as a professor for two decades. His career was marred by a significant scandal involving the theft of over 3,000 historical documents from various archives, driven by his interest in stamps. His thefts came to light in 2025, revealing a long history of misconduct that began shortly after he entered the field.

Name: Arvind Narayanan
info: Arvind Narayanan is a computer scientist and professor at Princeton University, where he serves as the director of the Center for Information Technology Policy. He is renowned for his research on the de-anonymization of data, notably demonstrating vulnerabilities in anonymized datasets through his work on the Netflix Prize competition. Narayanan has also advocated for privacy standards such as Do Not Track in web protocols and has contributed to discussions on ethics in computer science education. He holds a PhD from the University of Texas at Austin and has received several accolades, including the Presidential Early Career Award for Scientists and Engineers.

Name: Danqi Chen
info: Danqi Chen is a Chinese computer scientist and assistant professor at Princeton University, specializing in natural language processing. She joined the Princeton NLP group in 2019 after serving as a visiting scientist at Facebook AI Research. Chen earned her Ph.D. from Stanford University, where she developed algorithms that contributed to Google's SyntaxNet. Her notable works include her dissertation "Neural Reading Comprehension and Beyond" and the journal article "Reading Wikipedia to Answer Open-Domain Questions." She has received a gold medal at the 2008 International Informatics Olympiad and is recognized for her contributions to text understanding and knowledge representation.

Name: Ryan P. Adams
info: David Ryan Adams, born on November 5, 1974, is an American rock and country singer-songwriter known for his prolific output and diverse musical style. He gained prominence as a solo artist after leaving the band Whiskeytown, with his debut album Heartbreaker receiving critical acclaim in 2000. Adams continued to build his reputation with subsequent releases, including the gold-certified Gold and the classic Rock N Roll. He has produced albums for various artists and collaborated with notable musicians across genres. Despite facing personal and professional challenges, including allegations of misconduct, Adams has continued to release music, with six albums launched between 2020 and 2022. His literary contributions include poetry collections such as Infinity Blues and Hello Sunshine.

Name: John von Neumann
info: John Nepomucene Neumann was a Bohemian-born American prelate of the Catholic Church, known for his significant contributions to Catholic education in the United States. After immigrating to the U.S. in 1836, he was ordained and joined the Redemptorist order, eventually becoming the fourth Bishop of Philadelphia in 1852. Neumann founded the first Catholic diocesan school system in the U.S., which laid the groundwork for future Catholic education. He was canonized in 1977, becoming the only male U.S. citizen to be recognized as a saint.

Name: Robert Tarjan
info: Robert Endre Tarjan is an American computer scientist and mathematician, born on April 30, 1948. He is renowned for his contributions to graph theory algorithms, including the strongly connected components algorithm, and for co-inventing data structures such as splay trees and Fibonacci heaps. Tarjan has held the position of James S. McDonnell Distinguished University Professor of Computer Science at Princeton University since 1985, and he has also worked at various prestigious institutions including AT&T Bell Labs and Microsoft Research. He received the Turing Award in 1986 for his fundamental achievements in algorithm design and analysis, and he is a member of several esteemed academies, including the National Academy of Sciences and the National Academy of Engineering.

Name: William Bialek
info: William Samuel Bialek is a theoretical biophysicist and a professor at Princeton University and The Graduate Center, CUNY. His research focuses on the intersection of physics and biology, particularly on the optimal functions of living systems and the application of information theory to neural encoding. Bialek has authored influential works, including the textbook "Spikes: Exploring the Neural Code" and "Biophysics: Searching for Principles." He has received several honors, including the 2013 Swartz Prize for Theoretical and Computational Neuroscience and the Max Delbruck Prize in 2017, and is a member of the National Academy of Sciences. He is actively involved in educational initiatives aimed at integrating mathematics and natural sciences for first-year college students.

Name: Yael Niv
info: Yael Niv is a neuroscientist specializing in reinforcement learning and decision making in both humans and animals. She serves as a Professor of Psychology and Neuroscience at Princeton University, where she has made significant contributions to understanding the neural and computational processes underlying reinforcement learning. Niv is also an advocate for gender equality in science, founding biaswatchneuro.com to address sexism in neuroscience. Her notable awards include the National Academy of Sciences Troland Research Award and the Presidential Early Career Award for Scientists and Engineers. Niv's research emphasizes the development of neurocognitive models that explain brain mechanisms and their computational algorithms.

Name: Paul Chirik
info: Paul James Chirik is an American chemist born on June 13, 1973, recognized for his innovative work in sustainable chemistry, particularly using Earth-abundant metals like iron, cobalt, and nickel in catalysis. He is the Edwards S. Sanford Professor of Chemistry and chair of the chemistry department at Princeton University. Chirik earned his B.S. from Virginia Tech and his Ph.D. from the California Institute of Technology, later joining Cornell University before moving to Princeton in 2011. His notable contributions include developing recyclable plastics through iron-catalyzed depolymerization and advancing iron- and cobalt-based cross-coupling techniques crucial for pharmaceutical development. Chirik has received several awards, including the Gabor Somorjai Award for Creative Research in Catalysis in 2021 and was named a Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science in 2023. He has served as the editor-in-chief of the journal Organometallics since 2015.

Name: Olga Russakovsky
info: Olga Russakovsky is an associate professor of computer science at Princeton University, specializing in computer vision and machine learning. She played a pivotal role in the development of ImageNet, a large-scale visual recognition database, and has conducted significant research on algorithmic bias and fairness in AI systems. Her notable contributions include the lead authorship of a highly cited paper on the ImageNet challenge, which has influenced advancements in object classification. Russakovsky has received several accolades, including recognition as one of MIT Technology Review's top young innovators and the Anita Borg Early Career Award. She is actively involved in initiatives aimed at improving diversity in AI and enhancing public understanding of the field.

Name: Elliott Lieb
info: Elliott Hershel Lieb is an esteemed American mathematical physicist born in 1932, currently serving as a professor of mathematics and physics at Princeton University. His research focuses on the quantum and classical many-body problem, atomic structure, stability of matter, functional inequalities, magnetism theory, and the Hubbard model. Lieb has made significant contributions to statistical mechanics, including the exact solutions of various models and the development of the Lieb-Robinson bounds, which have implications in quantum computing. He has received numerous prestigious awards, including the Heineman Prize, the Max Planck Medal, and the Kyoto Prize in Basic Sciences, and is a member of the U.S. National Academy of Sciences.

Name: Peter Dayan
info: Peter Dayan is a British neuroscientist and computer scientist currently serving as a director at the Max Planck Institute for Biological Cybernetics in Tübingen, Germany. He is a pioneer in reinforcement learning, notably proposing that dopamine signals reward prediction error and contributing to the development of the Q-learning algorithm. Dayan co-authored the influential textbook "Theoretical Neuroscience" and is recognized for applying Bayesian methods to neural function, particularly in relating neurotransmitter levels to prediction errors. His notable contributions include the wake-sleep algorithm for neural networks and the Helmholtz machine. He has received several accolades, including being elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in 2018 and receiving the Rumelhart Prize in 2012 and The Brain Prize in 2017.

Name: Sharon Hammes-Schiffer
info: Sharon Hammes-Schiffer is a distinguished physical chemist known for her significant contributions to theoretical and computational chemistry, particularly in the areas of proton-coupled electron transfer, enzymatic processes, and the nuclear-electronic orbital method. She is currently the A. Barton Hepburn Professor of Chemistry at Princeton University and has held faculty positions at several prestigious institutions, including the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign and Yale University. Hammes-Schiffer's research has advanced the understanding of chemical reactions in various contexts, including enzyme catalysis and energy conversion processes, and she has authored nearly 200 papers. Her work has garnered numerous accolades, including election to the American Philosophical Society in 2024 and fellowships in several scientific societies.

Name: Weinan E
info: Weinan E is a prominent Chinese mathematician born in September 1963, recognized for his significant contributions to applied mathematics and machine learning. His work encompasses stochastic differential equations, multiscale modeling, and the application of deep learning techniques to scientific computing, with notable achievements in developing algorithms for fluid dynamics and chemistry. E is currently a professor at Princeton University and Peking University, and he serves as the inaugural director of the Beijing Institute of Big Data Research. His accolades include the Presidential Early Career Award, the ICIAM Collatz Prize, and the Peter Henrici Prize, and he has been invited as a plenary speaker at the International Congress of Mathematicians.

Name: Upmanu Lall
info: Upmanu Lall is an Indian American engineer and the founding director of the Water Institute at Arizona State University, where he also serves as a professor in the School of Complex Adaptive Systems. Previously, he was the Alan and Carol Silberstein Professor of Engineering at Columbia University, where he directed the Columbia Water Center. Lall's research focuses on hydrology, climate dynamics, and water systems, particularly in addressing water scarcity and flood prediction. He has received numerous accolades, including the Henry Darcy Medal and recognition as a fellow of the American Geophysical Union and the American Association for the Advancement of Science. His current work emphasizes sustainable water management and resilience to climate change.

Name: Daniel Hsu
info: Daniel Hsu is an American classical pianist born on June 27, 1997, in Fremont, California. He gained early recognition by winning the San Francisco Chopin Competition at age 8 and has since performed with prestigious orchestras worldwide, including the Philadelphia Orchestra and the Tokyo Symphony Orchestra. Hsu achieved notable success at the Fifteenth Van Cliburn International Piano Competition, where he won the bronze medal and multiple awards for his performances. He released his debut album, "Cliburn Bronze," in 2017 and is currently the Richard A. Doran Fellow at the Curtis Institute of Music, pursuing a Bachelor of Music in piano performance. In addition to his musical career, Hsu has contributed to computer programming projects, including the award-winning app Workflow.

Name: kartik chandran
info: Kartik Chandran is an American environmental engineer and professor in the Department of Earth and Environmental Engineering at Columbia University. His research integrates environmental molecular microbiology, biotechnology, and engineering, focusing on the nitrogen cycle's microbial ecology and metabolic pathways. Notable contributions include pioneering resource recovery programs for biological wastewater treatment at Columbia and receiving the MacArthur Fellowship in 2015 for his innovative work in transforming wastewater into a valuable resource. Chandran holds a B.S. in chemical engineering from the University of Roorkee and a Ph.D. in environmental engineering from the University of Connecticut, and he has authored several significant publications in the field.

Name: vapnik
info: Vladimir Naumovich Vapnik, born on December 6, 1936, is a prominent statistician and researcher known for his significant contributions to statistical learning theory, particularly the Vapnik–Chervonenkis theory and the development of support-vector machines and support-vector clustering algorithms. After earning his master's degree in mathematics and a Ph.D. in statistics, he worked at the Institute of Control Sciences in Moscow before moving to the United States in 1990, where he joined AT&T Bell Labs and later NEC Laboratories. Vapnik has held professorships at Royal Holloway, University of London, and Columbia University, and he is currently affiliated with Meta AI. His accolades include induction into the U.S. National Academy of Engineering and numerous awards such as the IEEE John von Neumann Medal and the BBVA Foundation Frontiers of Knowledge Award.

Name: Tim Roughgarden
info: Timothy Avelin Roughgarden is an American computer scientist and a professor of Computer Science at Columbia University, specializing in game theory and algorithms. He earned his Ph.D. from Cornell University in 2002 and has held faculty positions at Stanford University from 2004 to 2018. Roughgarden's notable contributions include his research on routing traffic in large-scale communication networks, for which he received several awards, including the Gödel Prize in 2012 and the Grace Murray Hopper Award in 2009. He is also the author of key works such as "Twenty Lectures on Algorithmic Game Theory" and "Selfish Routing and the Price of Anarchy," and he co-edited the textbook "Algorithmic Game Theory."

Name: Zhou Yu
info: Zhou Yu was a prominent Chinese military general and strategist during the late Eastern Han dynasty, serving under warlords Sun Ce and Sun Quan. He is best known for his strategic leadership in the decisive victories at the Battle of Red Cliffs and the Battle of Jiangling, which were crucial in establishing the foundation of Eastern Wu, one of the Three Kingdoms. Despite his early death at the age of 35, Zhou Yu's contributions significantly shaped the military landscape of his time. His legacy is celebrated in historical texts, although some of his popular monikers emerged later in folklore.

Name: Omar M. Yaghi
info: Omar Mwannes Yaghi, born on February 9, 1965, is a prominent chemist recognized for his pioneering work in reticular chemistry and the development of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). He was awarded the 2025 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for his significant contributions to these fields. Yaghi holds the position of University Professor and James and Neeltje Tretter Endowed Chair in Chemistry at the University of California, Berkeley, and is an affiliate scientist at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. He has also founded the Berkeley Global Science Institute and serves as the seventh president of the World Cultural Council. His research has led to breakthroughs in MOFs, covalent organic frameworks (COFs), and molecular weaving, with applications in clean energy technologies and environmental sustainability.

Name: Jitendra MALIK
info: Jitendra Malik is an Indian-American academic and the Arthur J. Chick Professor of Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences at the University of California, Berkeley. He is renowned for his contributions to computer vision, having developed influential concepts and algorithms such as anisotropic diffusion and R-CNN. Malik has mentored over 60 PhD students and postdoctoral fellows, many of whom have secured faculty positions at prestigious institutions. His research has garnered significant recognition, with over 150,000 citations and numerous awards, including the IEEE Computer Society's Computer Pioneer Award in 2019. He is also a fellow of several esteemed organizations, including the IEEE and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.

Name: Jeffrey R LONG
info: Jeffrey Long is an American physician and researcher specializing in near-death experiences (NDEs). He practices radiation oncology in Kentucky and is the founder of the Near Death Experience Research Foundation, which houses the largest database of near-death reports globally. Long is the author of the New York Times Best Seller "Evidence of the Afterlife: The Science of Near-Death Experiences" and has contributed to significant publications in the field, including "The Handbook of Near-Death Experiences." He is also a board member of the American Center for the Integration of Spiritually Transformative Experiences.

Name: Peidong Yang
info: Peidong Yang is a prominent Chinese-American chemist and material scientist, currently serving as the S.K. and Angela Chan Distinguished Professor of Energy, as well as a Professor of Chemistry and Materials Science at the University of California, Berkeley. He is also a Senior Faculty Scientist at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory and holds leadership roles in several research initiatives. Yang's research focuses on semiconductor nanowires and their applications in energy conversion, including the invention of the first nanowire nanolaser and the development of innovative nanostructures for energy efficiency. He has received numerous accolades, including the MacArthur Genius Fellowship and membership in the National Academy of Sciences, and has co-authored over 400 peer-reviewed articles. Yang continues to contribute to the field through his research and business ventures, including co-founding Alphabet Energy.

Name: Adam Paul Arkin
info: Adam Arkin is an accomplished American actor and director, born on August 19, 1956. He gained prominence for his role as Aaron Shutt on the television series Chicago Hope and has received multiple nominations for prestigious awards, including a Tony Award and three Primetime Emmys. Notable for his diverse roles, he portrayed characters in series such as Northern Exposure, Life, and Sons of Anarchy, and directed episodes of acclaimed shows like Grey's Anatomy and Fargo. Arkin won a Daytime Emmy for directing My Louisiana Sky and continues to contribute to the television industry as a co-executive producer of Get Shorty. He is currently affiliated with various television projects while maintaining a rich career in both acting and directing.

Name: Shannon Boettcher
info: Shannon W. Boettcher is an American chemist and chemical engineer, currently serving as the Theodore Vermeulen Professor in the Departments of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering and Chemistry at UC Berkeley. His research focuses on materials science and electrochemistry, particularly in energy conversion and storage. Boettcher has received numerous accolades, including being named a DuPont Young Professor, a Cottrell Scholar, a Sloan Fellow, and a Camille Dreyfus Teacher-Scholar. He founded the Oregon Center for Electrochemistry in 2019 and initiated the first targeted graduate program in electrochemical technology in 2020. In recognition of his contributions, he was named a Blavatnik National Award Finalist in 2021 and a Laureate in 2023.

Name: Ken Goldberg
info: Kenneth Yigael Goldberg is an American artist, writer, inventor, and researcher in robotics and automation, currently serving as professor and chair of the industrial engineering and operations research department at the University of California, Berkeley. He holds the William S. Floyd Jr. Distinguished Chair in Engineering and has joint appointments in Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences, Art Practice, and the School of Information. Goldberg has made significant contributions to the field, including developing the first algorithm for orienting polygonal parts and co-founding the African Robotics Network. His notable works include the Telegarden, a pioneering internet-connected robot, and various projects in collaborative filtering and data visualization. He has received numerous awards, including the Joseph F. Engelberger Robotics Award and has been recognized as an IEEE Fellow for his contributions to networked telerobotics.

Name: Ali Javey
info: Ali Javey is a professor of electrical engineering and computer sciences at the University of California, Berkeley, and a senior faculty scientist at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. He co-directs the Bay Area Photovoltaic Consortium and the Berkeley Sensor and Actuator Center, focusing on materials and device innovation in areas such as photovoltaics, wearable sensors, nanoelectronics, and programmable materials. Javey has received numerous accolades, including the Dan Maydan Prize in Nanoscience and Nanotechnology and the MRS Outstanding Young Investigator Award. He serves as an Associate Editor for ACS Nano and has been recognized as a Bakar Fellow at UC Berkeley.

Name: Daniel A Fletcher
info: Daniel Fletcher was an Australian rules footballer who played for Geelong in the Australian Football League in 1994 after being recruited from the Geelong Falcons. Following his playing career, he served as a coach for St Mary's in the Geelong Football League from 2007 to 2011, leading the team to a Premiership in 2008. Fletcher's life ended tragically in October 2015 at the age of 41 when he was found deceased in Lorne, Victoria. His brother, Simon Fletcher, also had a career in the AFL, playing for Carlton.

Name: Trevor Darrell
info: Trevor Jackson Darrell is an American computer scientist and professor at the University of California, Berkeley, specializing in computer vision and machine learning. He is recognized as a leading expert in deep learning and explainable AI, and his research group developed the Caffe deep-learning library. Darrell earned his Ph.D. from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and has held positions at Interval Research Corporation and MIT before joining UC Berkeley in 2008, where he co-founded the BAIR laboratory. His notable former students include prominent figures in the field, and he continues to contribute significantly to advancements in artificial intelligence.

Name: Bin YU
info: Bin Yu is a Chinese-American statistician and Chancellor's Professor in the Departments of Statistics and Electrical Engineering & Computer Sciences at the University of California, Berkeley. She earned her bachelor's degree in mathematics from Peking University and completed her master's and Ph.D. in statistics at Berkeley. Yu's research encompasses statistics, machine learning, neuroscience, genomics, and remote sensing, with a focus on data science and interpretable machine learning. She has received numerous accolades, including fellowships from several prestigious organizations and the COPSS Distinguished Achievement Award in 2023. Yu has also contributed significantly to theoretical foundations of deep learning and COVID-19 severity forecasting.

Name: Daniel Nomura
info: Daniel K. Nomura is an American chemical biologist and Professor of Chemical Biology and Molecular Therapeutics at the University of California, Berkeley. His research focuses on using chemoproteomic approaches to develop small molecule therapeutics targeting traditionally "undruggable" proteins, leading to significant discoveries such as novel inhibitors and the Deubiquitinase Targeting Chimera platform. Nomura has received several accolades, including the Mark Foundation for Cancer Research ASPIRE award and the National Cancer Institute Outstanding Investigator Award. He is also involved in various advisory roles and initiatives, including serving as Co-Director of the Molecular Therapeutics Initiative and Director of the Novartis-Berkeley Translational Chemical Biology Institute.

Name: Richard IVRY
info: Richard B. Ivry is an American cognitive neuroscientist and Distinguished Professor in the Department of Psychology at the University of California, Berkeley, where he is also a founding member of the Helen Wills Neuroscience Institute. His influential research has significantly advanced the understanding of perception and action. Ivry earned his Bachelor of Arts in psychology from Brown University and completed his Master of Science and Ph.D. at the University of Oregon. He has received several prestigious awards, including a Sloan Research Fellowship in neuroscience, a Troland Research Award, and the William James Fellow Award.

Name: Francesco Borrelli
info: Francesco Borrelli is a prominent figure in the field of electrical and computer engineering, currently affiliated with the University of California, Berkeley. He is recognized for his significant contributions to the theory and application of model predictive control. In 2016, he was honored as a Fellow of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) for his impactful work in this area.

Name: Enrique Iglesia
info: Enrique Iglesia is a distinguished chemical engineer currently holding the Theodore Vermeulen Chair in Chemical Engineering at the University of California, Berkeley, where he also serves as a Faculty Senior Scientist at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. He earned his B.S. from Princeton University, followed by an M.S. and Ph.D. from Stanford University, and began his career at Exxon Research focusing on catalytic processes. Iglesia has made significant contributions to catalysis, particularly in sustainable energy and environmental protection, and is known for his zeolite-based technology used in the oil and chemical industry. He has received numerous accolades, including election to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and the National Academy of Engineering, and has been honored with several prestigious awards for his research and teaching excellence.

Name: Joel E. MOORE
info: Joel David Moore is an American character actor and director, born on September 25, 1977, in Portland, Oregon. He gained prominence with his role as Owen Dittman in the 2004 film Dodgeball: A True Underdog Story and has appeared in notable films such as Grandma's Boy, Art School Confidential, and the slasher film Hatchet. Moore is well-known for his portrayal of Dr. Norm Spellman in James Cameron's Avatar and its sequels, as well as his recurring role as Colin Fisher on the series Bones. In addition to acting, he has directed films including the psychological thriller Spiral and the drama Youth in Oregon. Moore continues to be active in the film industry, with upcoming appearances in Avatar: Fire and Ash.

Name: Martin HEAD-GORDON
info: Martin Paul Head-Gordon is a professor of chemistry at the University of California, Berkeley, and the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, specializing in computational quantum chemistry. He earned his Bachelor and Master of Science degrees from Monash University and a PhD from Carnegie Mellon University, where he developed significant techniques in quantum chemistry, including the Head-Gordon-Pople scheme. At Berkeley, he leads research on various advanced computational methods and is a co-founder of Q-Chem Inc. In recognition of his contributions to the field, he was elected a Member of the National Academy of Sciences in 2015.

Name: Polly Louise Arnold
info: Polly Louise Arnold is a British chemist and the director of the chemical sciences division at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, as well as a professor of chemistry at the University of California, Berkeley. Her research specializes in exploratory synthetic chemistry, particularly focusing on early transition metal, lanthanide, and actinide chemistry, which is crucial for catalyst discovery and understanding nuclear waste behavior. Arnold has received numerous accolades, including the Rosalind Franklin Award, the Royal Society of Chemistry's Corday-Morgan Prize, and was appointed Officer of the Order of the British Empire for her contributions to chemistry and advocacy for women in STEM. She is a Fellow of the Royal Society and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and she actively promotes diversity in the STEM workforce through public speaking and media engagement.

Name: Dacher Keltner
info: Dacher Joseph Keltner is a Mexican-born American professor of psychology at the University of California, Berkeley, where he directs the Berkeley Social Interaction Lab. His research focuses on the cultural and evolutionary origins of emotions such as compassion, awe, and love, as well as social class and inequality. Keltner is the author of several influential books, including Born to Be Good and AWE: The New Science of Everyday Wonder, and has published over 230 scientific articles. He has received numerous awards for his contributions to psychology and is a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. Keltner also engages in public outreach through his Science of Happiness MOOC and collaborations with organizations like Pixar and the Sierra Club.

Name: Kevin E. Healy
info: Kevin Martin Healy was an Australian communist activist and trade unionist born in 1909 in Fremantle. He became involved in radical politics in the late 1920s, joining the Communist Party of Australia in 1937 and later serving as chairman of the party's state committee. Notably, he was charged with sedition in 1949 but successfully defended himself and was acquitted. In the early 1950s, he relocated to New South Wales, where he worked at Mort's Dock and became active in Aboriginal issues, founding the Ryde Aboriginal Interest Group in 1992. Healy passed away in 2001.

Name: Joan Walker
info: Joan Walker, née Suter, was a Canadian writer born on November 21, 1908, in London, England, and she passed away on July 27, 1997. She made significant contributions to Canadian literature, winning the Stephen Leacock Award in 1954 for her humorous memoir Pardon My Parka and the Ryerson Fiction Award in 1957 for her novel Repent at Leisure, which explores themes of marriage and personal struggle. Walker worked in various roles, including as a fashion artist and editor, before becoming a Canadian citizen in 1954. In addition to her notable works, she was an active member of the Canadian Women's Press Club and the Canadian Authors Association, and she later served as a columnist and book reviewer for The Globe and Mail.

Name: Steven G. Louie
info: Steven Gwon Sheng Louie is a prominent computational condensed-matter physicist, currently serving as a professor of physics at the University of California, Berkeley, and as a senior faculty scientist at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. His research primarily focuses on nanoscience, and he is the scientific director of the Theory of Nanostructured Materials Facility at the Molecular Foundry. Louie earned his PhD from Berkeley in 1976 under the guidance of Professor Marvin L. Cohen. He has received numerous accolades for his contributions to the field, including being named a Fellow of the American Physical Society, receiving the Aneesur Rahman Prize for Computational Physics, and the Davisson-Germer Prize in Surface Physics, among others. He is also a member of the National Academy of Sciences and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.

Name: Haimei Zheng
info: Haimei Zheng is a Chinese-American materials scientist currently serving as a senior scientist in the Materials Sciences Division at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory and as an adjunct professor in the Department of Materials Science and Engineering at the University of California, Berkeley. Her research focuses on nucleation, nanoscale materials transformations, and dynamic phenomena at solid-liquid interfaces, utilizing advanced in situ electron microscopy techniques. Zheng has published over 140 papers and has received several accolades, including the Materials Research Society Graduate Student Gold Medal Award and the MRS Medal Award. She was elected a Fellow of the Materials Research Society in 2021.

Name: Graham Fleming
info: Graham R. Fleming is a professor of chemistry at the University of California, Berkeley, and a member of the Kavli Energy NanoScience Institute. His research focuses on advanced multidimensional, ultrafast spectroscopy to investigate complex condensed phase dynamics in systems such as natural photosynthetic complexes and nanoscale materials. Notable contributions from his team include demonstrating the significance of quantum electronic coherence in biological energy harvesting processes. Fleming has published extensively, with key works appearing in prestigious journals like Science and Nature. He has received several accolades throughout his career, including the Melvin Calvin Distinguished Professor of Chemistry title at UC Berkeley, and served as vice-chancellor for research at the university from 2009 to 2015.

Name: Luke P. Lee
info: Luke Lee Wen Loong is a Singaporean actor and lawyer, recognized for his role as Sergeant Heng in the popular army films Ah Boys to Men and Ah Boys to Men 2. He studied law at the University of Manchester, graduating with Honours in 2015, and was subsequently called to the Singapore Bar. Lee's acting career began with hosting the 2009 Asian Youth Games and has since included notable roles in MediaCorp's Tanglin and the horror film A Fantastic Ghost Wedding. He has expressed a desire to elevate Singapore's action film industry and is currently in talks to produce and star in a new project titled Burn.

Name: Dmitry Budker
info: Dmitry Budker is a Russian-American physicist born in 1963, recognized for his significant contributions to atomic, molecular, and optical physics, particularly in precision measurements and fundamental symmetries. He is currently a Professor at Johannes Gutenberg University of Mainz and the Helmholtz Institute Mainz in Germany, as well as a Professor of the Graduate School at the University of California, Berkeley. Notable achievements include observing the largest atomic parity violation using ytterbium isotopes, conducting tests of the spin-statistics theorem, and developing atomic sensor techniques for dark matter detection. Budker has received several awards, including the American Physical Society Award for Outstanding Doctoral Thesis Research and the Norman F. Ramsey Prize.

Name: Scott Shenker
info: Scott J. Shenker is an American computer scientist and professor at the University of California, Berkeley, where he leads the Extensible Internet Group at the International Computer Science Institute. His research has significantly advanced the fields of energy-efficient processor scheduling, resource sharing, and software-defined networking, with notable contributions including the concept of Dominant Resource Fairness. Shenker has received several prestigious awards, including the SIGCOMM Award and the IEEE Internet Award, and he is recognized as an ISI Highly Cited researcher. He is a Fellow of the ACM and IEEE, a member of the National Academy of Engineering, and a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. In 2021, he made headlines for donating $25 million to support computing and data science initiatives at Berkeley.

Name: Nicholas Ingolia
info: Nicholas Thomas Ingolia is an American molecular biologist and professor at the University of California, Berkeley, born on February 5, 1979. He is renowned for developing ribosome profiling, a significant method in molecular biology. His research also includes the evolution of heat-sensing nerves in vampire bats and the encoding of small peptides by brief open reading frames. Ingolia was recognized as a Searle Scholar in 2011 and is involved in peer review for the American Cancer Society.

Name: David Whitney
info: David Whitney was an influential American art curator, collector, gallerist, and critic, known for his significant contributions to the contemporary art scene from the 1960s onward. He opened the David Whitney Gallery in 1969, showcasing prominent artists such as Jasper Johns and Cy Twombly, and later organized exhibitions at the Whitney Museum featuring renowned figures like Andy Warhol and Willem de Kooning. Whitney was a close associate of Warhol and served on the Andy Warhol Art Authentication Board. He was the long-term partner of architect Philip Johnson and, upon his death in 2005, bequeathed his estate to the National Trust for Historic Preservation and donated artworks to the Menil Collection.

Name: Ulrike Malmendier
info: Ulrike M. Malmendier is a German economist and professor of economics and finance at the University of California, Berkeley. Her research primarily focuses on behavioral economics, corporate finance, and law and economics, with notable contributions including studies on CEO overconfidence and the long-term effects of economic experiences on financial behavior. Malmendier has received several prestigious awards, including the Fischer Black Prize in 2013 and the Gustav Stolper Prize in 2019, and she is recognized among the top 5% most cited economists. She currently serves as a research associate at the National Bureau of Economic Research and was appointed by the German government as one of the economic experts on the German Council of Economic Experts.

Name: David Card
info: David Edward Card is a Canadian-American labour economist and the Class of 1950 Professor of Economics at the University of California, Berkeley, where he has been since 1997. He was awarded half of the 2021 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences for his empirical contributions to labour economics, particularly his influential research on the effects of minimum wage and immigration on the labor market. Notable works include "Myth and Measurement: The New Economics of Minimum Wage," which challenged prevailing beliefs about minimum wage impacts on employment. Card has received several accolades, including the John Bates Clark Medal in 1995 and has served in editorial roles for prominent economic journals. He continues to contribute to the field through his research and teaching at Berkeley.

Name: Ralph Weissleder
info: Ralph Weissleder is an American clinician scientist and professor at Harvard Medical School, where he also serves as the director of the Center for Systems Biology at Massachusetts General Hospital. He graduated from the University of Heidelberg in 1985 and has since made significant contributions to biotechnology, particularly in molecular imaging and next-generation diagnostics. Weissleder has published nearly 1,000 peer-reviewed articles, holds 78 patents, and has been recognized with numerous awards, including membership in the National Academy of Medicine and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. He is actively involved in clinical practice in interventional radiology, focusing on biliary procedures, and has trained over 200 clinical fellows.

Name: Heng Li
info: Heng Li is a prominent Chinese bioinformatics scientist currently serving as an associate professor in the Department of Biomedical Informatics at Harvard Medical School and the Department of Data Science at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute. He has made significant contributions to next generation sequencing, particularly through the development of influential software tools such as SAMtools and the Burrows-Wheeler aligner (BWA). Li's research has garnered over 50,000 citations for his key works, and he received the Benjamin Franklin award in bioinformatics in 2012. He has been recognized as an ISCB Fellow since 2023.

Name: James M. Robins
info: James M. Robins is an esteemed epidemiologist and biostatistician recognized for his pioneering work in causal inference methodologies applicable to complex observational studies and randomized trials, particularly those involving time-dependent treatments. He has made significant contributions to the field, including the introduction of the G-formula, G-Estimation of Structural Nested Models, and Marginal Structural Models, which have influenced various disciplines such as biostatistics, epidemiology, and machine learning. Robins has authored over 100 academic papers and has received prestigious awards, including the Nathan Mantel Award and the Rousseeuw Prize in Statistics. He currently holds the position of Mitchell L. and Robin LaFoley Dong Professor of Epidemiology at Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health.

Name: Chelsea Finn
info: Chelsea Finn is an American computer scientist and assistant professor at Stanford University, specializing in the intersection of robotics and machine learning. Her research focuses on developing robotic systems that can learn to learn, utilizing meta-learning techniques to enhance adaptability in new scenarios. Finn earned her Ph.D. from the University of California, Berkeley, where she contributed to the field with gradient-based algorithms and deep learning approaches for visual perception and robotic control.
