She has received numerous accolades, including the C.V. & Daulat Ramamoorthy Distinguished Research Award and recognition as one of MIT Technology Review's 35 Under 35. Currently, she is affiliated with the Google Brain group and continues to advance the capabilities of intelligent robotic systems.

Name: Anne Brunet
info: Anne Brunet is a French geneticist and the Michele and Timothy Barakett Endowed Professor at Stanford University School of Medicine, where she co-directs the Paul F. Glenn Laboratories for the Biology of Aging. Her research focuses on the mechanisms of aging and longevity, including the discovery of lifespan-regulating genes and their interactions with environmental factors. Notable contributions include her work on pro-longevity genes and the development of the African killifish as a model for aging studies. Brunet has received several accolades, including the 2022 Lurie Prize in Biomedical Sciences and a research grant from the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative. She has been a faculty member at Stanford since 2004 and serves on the editorial board for Genes & Development.

Name: Shanhui Fan
info: Shanhui Fan is a Chinese-born American electrical engineer and physicist, specializing in photonics and electromagnetism. He is a professor of electrical engineering and applied physics at Stanford University, where he also serves as the director of the Edward L. Ginzton Lab and is a Senior Fellow at the Precourt Institute for Energy. His research encompasses nanophotonics, photonic crystals, metamaterials, and solar cells, and he holds approximately 57 patents. Fan has received numerous accolades, including the R. W. Wood Prize from Optica in 2022 and the Vannevar Bush Faculty Fellowship in 2017, recognizing his significant contributions to the field.

Name: Geoffrey C. Gurtner
info: Geoffrey C. Gurtner is an American microsurgeon and the Chair of Surgery, as well as a Professor of Surgery and Biomedical Engineering at the University of Arizona College of Medicine – Tucson. He previously served as a Professor of Surgery and the Inaugural Vice Chairman of Surgery for Innovation at Stanford University School of Medicine. Gurtner is known for his pioneering work in scar research, regenerative healing, and innovative surgical techniques, including the development of a method to join severed blood vessels without sutures. His notable contributions include identifying the drug deferoxamine for enhancing wound healing in diabetics and creating a skin patch for delivering this drug. He has received several accolades, including the 2009 James Barrett Brown Award from the American Society of Plastic Surgeons, and served as President of the Wound Healing Society from 2019 to 2021.

Name: Liqun Luo
info: Liqun Luo is a prominent neuroscientist at Stanford University, where he serves as the Ann and Bill Swindells Professor in the Department of Biology and is an investigator at the Howard Hughes Medical Institute. His research focuses on the development and organization of neural circuits, and he has made significant contributions through the invention of tools for mosaic analysis in Drosophila and mice. Luo is the author of the textbook Principles of Neurobiology and has received numerous accolades, including membership in the National Academy of Sciences and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, as well as awards from the McKnight Foundation and the Society for Neuroscience.

Name: Robert M. Waymouth
info: Robert M. Waymouth is an American chemist and the Robert Eckles Swain Professor in Chemistry at Stanford University. He earned a B.S. in chemistry and a B.A. in mathematics from Washington and Lee University, followed by a PhD in chemistry from the California Institute of Technology. Since joining Stanford in 1988, he has focused on applying mechanistic principles to catalysis and has a notable interest in the disposal and recycling of plastics. He leads the Waymouth Group, contributing significantly to advancements in these areas.

Name: Pablo Jarillo-Herrero
info: Pablo Jarillo-Herrero is a Spanish physicist and the Cecil and Ida Green Professor of Physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He earned his Licenciatura in physics from the University of Valencia and completed his PhD at Delft University of Technology. Jarillo-Herrero is renowned for his groundbreaking work on graphene moiré superlattices, which has led to the discovery of electrically tunable superconductivity in this system. His numerous accolades include being named a Highly Cited Researcher, an APS Fellow, and receiving the prestigious Wolf Prize in Physics. He continues to contribute to the field of condensed matter physics through his research and teaching at MIT.

Name: Jonathan P. How
info: Jonathan P. How is a Canadian-American astrophysicist and aeronautical engineer, currently serving as the Richard Cockburn Maclaurin Professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. His research primarily focuses on technology systems engineering and space engineering. Born in England in 1965, he completed his bachelor's degree at the University of Toronto and earned both his master's and Ph.D. in aerospace engineering from MIT. How has held significant editorial roles, including editor-in-chief of IEEE Control Systems Magazine, and has received numerous awards for his contributions, including the AIAA Best Paper in Conference Award multiple times and the IFAC Automatica award. He is a Fellow of both the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics and the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, and in 2021, he was elected to the National Academy of Engineering for his work on intelligent autonomous aerospace vehicles.

Name: Noam Chomsky
info: Avram Noam Chomsky, born on December 7, 1928, is an influential American linguist, philosopher, and political activist, often referred to as the father of modern linguistics. He is a laureate professor of linguistics at the University of Arizona and an institute professor emeritus at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Chomsky is renowned for his development of transformational grammar and universal grammar theories, significantly impacting the fields of linguistics and cognitive science. His notable works include "Syntactic Structures" and "Manufacturing Consent," the latter co-authored with Edward S. Herman, which critiques media and propaganda. A prominent critic of U.S. foreign policy and contemporary capitalism, Chomsky has received numerous accolades for his contributions to linguistics and social criticism, remaining an active voice in political discourse.

Name: Mircea Dincă
info: Mircea Dincă is a Romanian-American inorganic chemist and the Andrew Stewart 1886 Professor of Chemistry at Princeton University. He is known for his pioneering work on functional metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), particularly in enhancing their electrical conductivity and exploring their applications in catalysis and materials science. Dincă completed his undergraduate studies at Princeton University and earned his Ph.D. from the University of California, Berkeley. He has held a faculty position at MIT before joining Princeton in 2025. His research has led to significant advancements in the understanding and application of MOFs, including the development of hybrid materials with enhanced properties.

Name: Shigehiro Oishi
info: Shigehiro Oishi is a prominent Japanese psychologist and author, currently serving as the Marshall Field IV professor of psychology at the University of Chicago. He is recognized as a leading authority on happiness, meaning, and culture, with over 200 published works and more than 100,000 citations. Oishi's notable contributions include research on cross-cultural differences in happiness, the relationship between income inequality and well-being, and the concept of psychological richness as a dimension of a good life. He has received several prestigious awards, including the Career Trajectory Award and the Diener Award, and his work has been featured in major media outlets. Oishi's academic journey includes degrees from the International Christian University, Teachers College at Columbia University, and the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.

Name: Chuan He
info: Chuan He is a Chinese-American chemical biologist and the John T. Wilson Distinguished Service Professor at the University of Chicago, as well as an Investigator at the Howard Hughes Medical Institute. He is renowned for his groundbreaking research on reversible RNA methylation and its regulatory roles in post-transcriptional gene expression, which earned him the 2023 Wolf Prize in Chemistry. His notable contributions include the invention of TAB-seq and hmC-Seal, methods for mapping and profiling 5-hydroxymethylcytosine. He has also identified the first RNA demethylase and characterized the reader proteins for m6A methylation, significantly advancing the understanding of mRNA modifications.

Name: Allison Okamura
info: Allison Mariko Okamura is an American mechanical engineer and roboticist known for her research in haptic technology, teleoperation, remote surgery, and robot-assisted surgery. She is the Richard W. Weiland Professor in the School of Engineering and a professor of mechanical engineering at Stanford University, where she leads the Collaborative Haptics and Robotics in Medicine laboratory and holds a courtesy appointment in computer science. Okamura has received several accolades, including the National Science Foundation CAREER Award, the IEEE Early Career Award, and recognition as an IEEE Fellow for her contributions to haptic systems and medical robotics. She served as editor-in-chief of IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters from 2018 to 2021.

Name: Leonidas Guibas
info: Leonidas John Guibas is the Paul Pigott Professor of Computer Science and Electrical Engineering at Stanford University, where he leads the Geometric Computation Group. He earned his Ph.D. from Stanford in 1976 and has made significant contributions to various areas of computer science, including algorithms, data structures, and computer vision. Notable works include the development of finger trees, the Guibas–Stolfi algorithm for Delaunay triangulation, and advancements in kinetic data structures. Guibas has received numerous accolades, including election to the National Academy of Engineering, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and the National Academy of Sciences, as well as being named a Fellow of the ACM and IEEE.

Name: Kathleen M. Eisenhardt
info: Kathleen Marie Eisenhardt is the Stanford W. Ascherman, M.D. Professor and co-director of the Stanford Technology Ventures Program at Stanford University. She is renowned for developing the Eisenhardt Method, which focuses on building theory through case comparisons. Eisenhardt has authored several influential works, including "Competing on the Edge" and "Simple Rules," and has published key articles in prestigious journals such as the Academy of Management Review and the Academy of Management Journal. In recognition of her contributions to entrepreneurship research, she received the Global Award for Entrepreneurship Research in 2012 and was elected a corresponding fellow of the British Academy in 2016.

Name: Robert Schoelkopf
info: Robert John Schoelkopf III is an American physicist renowned for his pioneering work in quantum computing, particularly as one of the inventors of superconducting qubits. His research encompasses quantum transport, single-electron devices, and charge dynamics in nanostructures, with a focus on developing superconducting devices for quantum information processing. Schoelkopf is a Professor of Physics and Sterling Professor of Applied Physics at Yale University, where he also directs the Yale Quantum Institute and the Yale Center for Microelectronic Materials and Structures. His notable contributions include the development of the Radio-Frequency Single-Electron Transistor and significant advancements in quantum error correction and superconducting quantum processors. He has received numerous accolades, including election to the National Academy of Sciences and the Comstock Prize in Physics.

Name: Jordan B Peterson
info: Jordan Bernt Peterson is a Canadian psychologist, author, and media commentator known for his controversial views on cultural and political issues. He earned a PhD in clinical psychology from McGill University and has held academic positions at Harvard University and the University of Toronto, where he became a full professor. Peterson's notable contributions include his first book, "Maps of Meaning: The Architecture of Belief," and the bestselling "12 Rules for Life: An Antidote to Chaos." He has received significant media attention for his critiques of political correctness and identity politics, particularly regarding Bill C-16 in Canada. Currently, he serves as chancellor of Ralston College, a private liberal arts institution in Georgia, and continues to engage with audiences through lectures and podcasts.

Name: michel devoret
info: Michel Henri Devoret is a French physicist born in 1953, currently serving as a Professor of Physics at the University of California, Santa Barbara, and as Chief Scientist of Quantum Hardware at Google Quantum AI. He is renowned for his significant contributions to superconducting quantum computing architectures, including the development of the quantronium, transmon, and fluxonium qubits. Devoret has received numerous accolades for his work, including the 2025 Nobel Prize in Physics, which he shared with John Clarke and John M. Martinis for their research on macroscopic quantum phenomena in superconducting circuits. He has also been elected to prestigious academies, including the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and the French Academy of Sciences.

Name: Yueh-Lin Loo
info: Yueh-Lin (Lynn) Loo is a Malaysian-born chemical engineer and the Theodora D. '78 and William H. Walton III '74 Professor in Engineering at Princeton University, where she also serves as the Director of the Andlinger Center for Energy and the Environment. She is renowned for her invention of nanotransfer printing, a technique that enables the printing of nanoscale patterns on plastic surfaces, facilitating the development of organic electronic devices. Loo's research focuses on block polymers, organic semiconductors, and innovative patterning techniques for plastic electronics. Her notable accolades include the Beckman Young Investigators Award, the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation Fellowship, and her election as a Fellow of both the American Physical Society and the Materials Research Society. She co-founded Andluca Technologies in 2017 and continues to advance research in solution-processable organic semiconductors and soft lithography.

Name: Sabine Kastner
info: Sabine Kastner is a prominent cognitive neuroscientist originally from Germany, currently serving as a professor of psychology at the Princeton Neuroscience Institute at Princeton University, with a visiting scientist role at the University of California at Berkeley. Her research has significantly advanced the understanding of attention mechanisms in the human brain, demonstrating that cognitive processes extend beyond the neocortex to include the thalamus. Kastner has received numerous accolades, including the Young Investigator Award from the Cognitive Neuroscience Society and the George A. Miller Prize in Cognitive Neuroscience. She is also the Editor-in-Chief of The Journal of Neuroscience and has been actively involved in public outreach to promote neuroscience education and support women in science.

Name: Daniel Kahneman
info: Daniel Kahneman was an Israeli-American psychologist renowned for his pioneering work in the psychology of judgment and decision-making, as well as behavioral economics. He was awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences in 2002 for integrating psychological insights into economic theory, particularly through his collaboration with Amos Tversky, which led to the development of prospect theory. Kahneman's influential book, Thinking, Fast and Slow, published in 2011, encapsulates much of his research and became a bestseller. He served as professor emeritus of psychology and public affairs at Princeton University and was recognized as one of the most influential economists globally. Kahneman's contributions have fundamentally challenged the notion of human rationality in economic decision-making.

Name: Ned S. Wingreen
info: Ned S. Wingreen is a theoretical physicist and the Howard A. Prior Professor of the Life Sciences at Princeton University, where he is also a member of the Department of Molecular Biology and the Lewis-Sigler Institute for Integrative Genomics. He is known for his contributions to mesoscopic physics, particularly the formulation of the Meir-Wingreen Formula, which describes electric current through mesoscopic systems. Wingreen's research interests have expanded to include biophysics, focusing on modeling intracellular networks in microorganisms. He has received several honors, including being named a fellow of the American Physical Society and the American Association for the Advancement of Science, and he was awarded the President's Award for Distinguished Teaching at Princeton University in 2019.

Name: Gregory Scholes
info: Gregory D. Scholes is the William S. Tod Professor of Chemistry at Princeton University, specializing in photosynthesis and quantum biology. He was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in 2019 in recognition of his significant contributions to the advancement of natural knowledge.

Name: Emily A. Carter
info: Emily Carter is an American writer known for her short stories and essays that often explore themes of addiction, alienation, illness, and recovery. Born on December 15, 1960, she is the daughter of feminist writer Anne Roiphe and playwright Jack Richardson. Carter's notable works include her collection "Glory Goes and Gets Some," which received critical acclaim for its raw depiction of drug use and the stigmatization of people with HIV/AIDS. She has received several awards, including the McKnight Foundation Artist Fellowship and the Whiting Award for Fiction. Currently, she continues to write and work as a community educator with the Minnesota AIDS Project.

Name: Andrew Gelman
info: Andrew Eric Gelman is an American statistician and the Higgins Professor of Statistics and a professor of political science at Columbia University. He is recognized for his significant contributions to statistical philosophy and methods, particularly in Bayesian statistics and hierarchical models, and is a key figure in the development of the statistical programming framework Stan. Gelman emphasizes a novel approach to statistical inference that prioritizes understanding variation and associations over traditional hypothesis testing. He has authored several influential works, including "Bayesian Data Analysis" and "Data Analysis Using Regression and Multilevel/Hierarchical Models." Gelman has received multiple awards from the American Statistical Association and was elected a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences in 2020.

Name: Rafael Yuste
info: Rafael Yuste is a Spanish-American neurobiologist born on April 25, 1963, in Madrid, Spain. He is a professor at Columbia University and a co-director of the Kavli Institute for Brain Science, where he has made significant contributions to the field of neuroscience, particularly through the development of calcium imaging techniques to monitor neuronal activity. Yuste is also one of the initiators of the BRAIN Initiative, which aims to advance brain research, and he has been instrumental in advocating for ethical guidelines in neurotechnology. His notable awards include the NIH Director's Pioneer Award and the Tällberg/Eliasson Global Leadership Prize. As of 2021, he has published over 260 papers and continues to influence the field through his research and leadership roles.

Name: Shree Nayar
info: Shree K. Nayar is an Indian American engineer and computer scientist renowned for his significant contributions to computer vision, computational imaging, and computer graphics. He serves as the T. C. Chang Professor of Computer Science at Columbia University, where he co-directs the Columbia Vision and Graphics Center and leads the Computer Vision Laboratory. Nayar's pioneering work includes the development of computational cameras and innovative imaging systems, with over 300 scientific publications and more than 80 patents to his name. He has received numerous accolades, including election to the US National Academy of Engineering and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, as well as several best paper awards and teaching honors.

Name: Hod Lipson
info: Hod Lipson is an Israeli-American robotics engineer and the director of Columbia University's Creative Machines Lab. His research focuses on evolutionary robotics, design automation, artificial life, and the development of machines that exhibit aspects of human creativity. Lipson has made significant contributions to machine learning, notably through the creation of the software Eureqa, which can derive mathematical laws from data. He has published extensively, with over 43,000 citations and an h-index of 86. Prior to his current role, he was a professor at Cornell University and has also held positions at Brandeis University and MIT.

Name: Brent R. Stockwell
info: Brent Roark Stockwell is an American chemical biologist and a Professor of Biological Sciences and Chemistry at Columbia University. He is renowned for coining the term ferroptosis in 2012 and for his significant contributions to understanding cell death mechanisms, particularly in cancer research. Stockwell's notable works include the development of the first library of biologically annotated compounds and the discovery of compounds like erastin, RSL3, and RSL5 that selectively kill tumor cells. He has received several accolades, including the Beckman Young Investigators Award, the Howard Hughes Medical Institute Early Career Scientist designation, and the Lenfest Distinguished Teaching Award. In 2023, he was elected to the National Academy of Medicine.

Name: Yuan Yang
info: Yuan Yang is a British Labour Party politician, economist, and journalist who has served as the Member of Parliament for Earley and Woodley since 2024, becoming the first Chinese-born Briton elected to the UK Parliament. She was previously the Europe–China correspondent for the Financial Times and has contributed to BBC News. Yang co-founded Rethinking Economics during the 2008 financial crisis, advocating for diverse economic education. Her notable work includes the book "Private Revolutions," published in 2024, which explores the lives of four women in China. Currently, she is a member of the Treasury Select Committee and chairs the All-Party Parliamentary Group for Social Science and Policy.

Name: Jushan Bai
info: Jushan Bai is a Chinese American economist and a professor of economics at Columbia University. He earned his B.A. from Nankai University, his M.A. from Pennsylvania State University, and his Ph.D. from the University of California, Berkeley. Bai has previously taught at prestigious institutions such as MIT, Boston College, and NYU before joining Columbia in 2008. He specializes in econometrics and is recognized as a leading economist of Chinese descent, having been elected a fellow of the Econometric Society in 2013.

Name: Timothy C. Wang
info: Timothy Wang is an American table tennis player known for his significant contributions to the sport. He competed in the Men's singles at the 2012 Summer Olympics and represented the United States in the men's team event at the 2016 Summer Olympics. Wang achieved notable success at the US National Championships, winning the men's singles title in 2010, 2012, and 2013, as well as securing national championships in men's doubles and mixed doubles during the same years. He is the son of Taiwanese immigrants.

Name: Lotfi A. Zadeh
info: Lotfi Aliasger Zadeh was a prominent mathematician, computer scientist, electrical engineer, and artificial intelligence researcher, best known for founding fuzzy mathematics, which includes fuzzy sets and fuzzy logic. He was a professor at the University of California, Berkeley, where he significantly influenced the integration of computer science into electrical engineering, transforming the department into the Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science. Zadeh's seminal works include his 1965 publication on fuzzy sets and his 1973 theory of fuzzy logic, which laid the groundwork for various innovations in control systems and artificial intelligence. He received numerous accolades, including a Guggenheim Fellowship and the IEEE Education Award, and he graduated over 50 PhD students during his career. Zadeh's legacy continues to impact multiple fields, reflecting his belief in the interconnectedness of cultures and ideas.

Name: Robert Thomas Knight
info: Robert M. Knight is a renowned rock and roll photographer with a career spanning approximately 40 years. He has made significant contributions to music photography, capturing iconic images of legendary musicians such as Jimi Hendrix, Stevie Ray Vaughan, and Eric Clapton. Knight is also an author and the subject of the documentary film "Rock Prophecies," which highlights his impact on the music industry.

Name: Terence Tao
info: Terence Chi-Shen Tao is an Australian and American mathematician, born on July 17, 1975, who is widely recognized for his contributions to various fields including harmonic analysis, partial differential equations, and number theory. He is a professor at the University of California, Los Angeles, holding the James and Carol Collins Chair, and has authored over three hundred research papers and sixteen books. Tao was awarded the Fields Medal in 2006, the Royal Medal and Breakthrough Prize in Mathematics in 2014, and is a MacArthur Fellow. He is known for his collaborative work, notably the Green-Tao theorem, which established the existence of arbitrarily long arithmetic progressions of prime numbers. As of 2022, he continues to be a leading figure in mathematics, recognized for his exceptional breadth and depth of knowledge.

Name: Matthew Lieberman
info: Matthew Dylan Lieberman is an American psychologist and professor at the University of California, Los Angeles, specializing in social neuroscience, affective neuroscience, and social psychology. He is known for his pioneering work in social cognitive neuroscience, particularly in understanding the neural mechanisms underlying social cognition, emotion regulation, and social experiences. Lieberman has authored key publications, including "Social: Why Our Brains Are Wired to Connect," and has received notable accolades such as the APA Distinguished Scientific Award for Early Career Contribution to Psychology and the UCLA Gold Shield Faculty Prize. He is also the founding editor of the journal Social Cognitive and Affective Neuroscience.

Name: Richard Kaner
info: Richard B. Kaner is an American synthetic inorganic chemist and a distinguished professor at the University of California, Los Angeles, where he holds the Dr. Myung Ki Hong Endowed Chair in Materials Innovation. His research focuses on conductive polymers, superhard materials, and carbon compounds, including fullerenes and graphene. Kaner has received numerous awards for his contributions to the field, including the ACS Award in Applied Polymer Science and the Royal Society of Chemistry Centenary Prize. He serves as Chief Scientific Adviser to several university spin-off companies and has held various academic positions, including adjunct professor at the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology.

Name: Behzad Razavi
info: Behzad Razavi is an Iranian-American professor and researcher in electrical and electronic engineering, currently serving as the director of the Communication Circuits Laboratory at the University of California Los Angeles. He is renowned for his contributions to telecommunications circuitry, particularly in low-power broadband communication circuits, and has authored several influential books in the field. Razavi has received numerous accolades, including the Beatrice Winner Award for Editorial Excellence and election to the National Academy of Engineering in 2017. He is a Fellow of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers and has held editorial roles for various professional journals.

Name: Naomi I. Eisenberger
info: Naomi I. Eisenberger is a social psychologist based at the University of California, Los Angeles, where she serves as a professor and directs the Social and Affective Neuroscience Laboratory. Her research focuses on the neural mechanisms underlying social pain and social connection, revealing that the brain regions activated by social rejection overlap with those activated by physical pain. Eisenberger's notable contributions include her influential paper "Does Rejection Hurt? An fMRI study of social exclusion," which demonstrated the neural correlates of social exclusion. She has received several awards for her work, including the IUPsyS Young Investigator Award in 2012 and the American Psychological Association Award for Distinguished Scientific Early Career Contributions to Psychology in 2013.

Name: Ying Nian Wu
info: Ming Qu and Ying Wu were Chinese graduate students at the University of Southern California who were tragically murdered on April 11, 2012, while sitting in their parked car near the campus. The crime, committed by two young men, Javier Bolden and Bryan Barnes, raised significant safety concerns in the surrounding area, known for its high crime rates. Both suspects were arrested shortly after the incident, with Barnes pleading guilty to murder in 2014 and receiving a life sentence without parole, followed by Bolden's conviction and similar sentencing later that year. The murders prompted a memorial attended by around a thousand people and led to criticism of the university regarding campus safety measures.

Name: Sarah H. Tolbert
info: Sarah Helen Tolbert is an American chemist and professor in the department of chemistry and biochemistry at the University of California, Los Angeles. Her research focuses on self-assembled nanomaterials, particularly the nanoscale assembly of inorganic and colloidal materials, which has implications for creating novel photonic materials and advanced battery technologies. Tolbert has made significant contributions to the development of nanostructured electrodes for fast-charging batteries and has explored the co-assembly of organic and inorganic materials. She has received several awards, including the Alfred P. Sloan Fellowship and the National Science Foundation CAREER Award, and is currently affiliated with Battery Streak, a company aimed at reducing charging times for electronic devices.

Name: song-chun zhu
info: Song-Chun Zhu is a prominent Chinese computer scientist and applied mathematician, recognized for his significant contributions to computer vision, cognitive artificial intelligence, and robotics. Currently affiliated with Peking University, he previously held professorships at UCLA, where he also directed the Center for Vision, Cognition, Learning and Autonomy. Zhu founded the Lotus Hill Institute to foster international collaboration in computer vision and has published extensively, earning accolades such as the IEEE Fellow designation in 2011 for his work on statistical modeling in computer vision. His research includes pioneering statistical models and developing a unified framework for vision and intelligence, and he is actively involved in establishing the Beijing Institute for General Artificial Intelligence to advance AI technology and education in China.

Name: David S. Eisenberg
info: David S. Eisenberg is an American biochemist and biophysicist, renowned for his work in structural biology and computational molecular biology. He has been a professor at the University of California, Los Angeles since the early 1970s and served as the director of the UCLA-DOE Institute for Genomics & Proteomics. His research primarily focuses on the structural biology of amyloidogenic proteins and the development of bioinformatic methodologies for analyzing protein interaction networks. Eisenberg has received numerous accolades, including the Harvey Prize in Human Health in 2008 and the Passano Award in 2020, and he is currently an investigator at the Howard Hughes Medical Institute.

Name: Prineha Narang
info: Prineha Narang is an American physicist and computational material scientist, currently serving as a Professor of Physical Sciences and Electrical and Computer Engineering at UCLA, where she holds the Howard Reiss Chair. Her research focuses on the interaction of quantum materials with electromagnetic radiation, contributing to advancements in quantum sensing, solid-state quantum repeaters, and the design of optimized materials at the nanoscale. Narang has received numerous accolades, including the Mildred Dresselhaus Prize, the IUPAP Young Scientist Prize in Computational Physics, and a Guggenheim Fellowship in 2023. She is also the founder and Chief Technology Officer of Aliro, a quantum network platform company, and has played significant roles in various scientific organizations and initiatives.

Name: Andrea Bertozzi
info: Andrea Louise Bertozzi is an American mathematician born in 1965, known for her research in non-linear partial differential equations and applied mathematics. She earned her bachelor's, master's, and PhD from Princeton University, with a dissertation focused on the Contour Dynamics Equation. Currently, she is a professor of mathematics and mechanical and aerospace engineering at UCLA, where she also serves as the Director of Applied Mathematics. Bertozzi has made significant contributions to various fields, including fluid dynamics, image processing, and the mathematics of crime, and has coauthored the influential book "Vorticity and Incompressible Flow." Her work has garnered numerous accolades, including election to the National Academy of Sciences and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and she has been recognized with multiple fellowships and awards throughout her career.

Name: Philippe Sautet
info: Philippe Sautet is a prominent French chemist born on May 8, 1961, in Salon-de-Provence, France. He specializes in the theory of heterogeneous catalysis and molecular modeling, contributing significantly to the understanding of surface interactions and catalytic mechanisms. Notable works include pioneering simulations of tunneling microscopy images, studies on the reactivity of palladium and rhodium, and the discovery of a new mechanism for hydrogenation on platinum. Sautet has received numerous accolades, including the CNRS silver medal and election to the French Academy of Sciences in 2010. He is currently a professor at the University of California, Los Angeles, after a distinguished career at various prestigious institutions in France.

Name: Kendall N. Houk
info: Kendall Newcomb Houk is a Distinguished Research Professor in Organic Chemistry at the University of California, Los Angeles, where he leads a research group focused on organic, organometallic, and biological reactions through computational chemistry. He has made significant contributions to the field, particularly in quantum mechanical calculations and molecular dynamics. Houk's notable awards include the Roger Adams Award from the American Chemical Society in 2021 and the Schrödinger Medal from the World Association of Theoretically Oriented Chemists in 1998. He has been recognized as a fellow of several prestigious organizations and was elected to the National Academy of Sciences in 2010.

Name: Christopher S Tang
info: Christopher Tang is a distinguished professor at the University of California, Los Angeles, where he has held the Edward W. Carter chair in business administration at the Anderson School of Management since 2002. He has made significant contributions to the fields of operations research and supply chain management, evidenced by his role as Editor-in-Chief of M&SOM and his leadership positions within INFORMS. Tang has authored and co-edited several key works, including "Managing Supply Chain Risk" and "Responsible and Sustainable Operations: The New Frontier." He has received numerous accolades, including being elected as a fellow of INFORMS, the Production and Operations Society, and the MSOM Society, and he was named a Hagler Fellow at Texas A&M University in 2024. Tang earned his PhD, MPhil, and MA from Yale University, and his BSc from King's College, London.

Name: Michelle Craske
info: Michelle G. Craske is an Australian academic born in 1959, currently serving as a Professor of Psychology, Psychiatry, and Behavioral Sciences at UCLA, where she also holds the Miller Endowed Chair and directs the Anxiety and Depression Research Center. Her notable contributions include extensive research on anxiety disorders, particularly phobias and panic disorders, and the development of exposure therapy techniques for treatment. Craske has authored several influential texts and over 460 peer-reviewed articles, and she has received numerous accolades, including an honorary doctorate from Maastricht University and the Distinguished Scientist Award from the Society for a Science of Clinical Psychology. In recognition of her distinguished service to psychology, she was appointed Officer of the Order of Australia in 2022.

Name: Adnan Darwiche
info: Adnan "Eddie" Darwiche is an Australian criminal from Sydney, currently serving life imprisonment for his involvement in two murders and multiple firearm assaults. He was convicted for the shooting of Bilal Razzak in 2001 and the attempted murder of Farouk Razzak in 2003, as well as for the Lawford Street murders of Ziad Razzak and Mervat Nemra in October 2003, where he and his accomplices fired over 100 rounds at their victims. Darwiche received two life sentences without the possibility of parole and an additional 20 years for other offenses. His criminal activities also included the alleged purchase of military-grade weapons, which were linked to broader criminal conspiracies.

Name: Alexander Kusenko
info: Alexander Kusenko is a theoretical physicist, astrophysicist, and cosmologist currently serving as a Professor of Physics and Astronomy at the University of California, Los Angeles. He is also a Senior Scientist at the Kavli Institute for the Physics and Mathematics of the Universe. Kusenko has made significant contributions to particle physics, astrophysics, and cosmology, earning him the status of Fellow of the American Physical Society in 2008 and a Simons Fellowship in Theoretical Physics in 2021. He has been involved with the Aspen Center for Physics as a board member from 2004 to 2019.

Name: Demetri Terzopoulos
info: Demetri Terzopoulos is a distinguished Greek-Canadian-American computer scientist and entrepreneur, currently serving as a Distinguished Professor and Chancellor's Professor of Computer Science at the University of California, Los Angeles, where he leads the UCLA Computer Graphics & Vision Laboratory. He earned his PhD in Artificial Intelligence from MIT, focusing on computer vision, and has held prominent academic positions at institutions such as the University of Toronto and New York University. Terzopoulos is renowned for his pioneering work in computer graphics, computer vision, and medical imaging, particularly for co-inventing the "active contours" algorithm and developing deformable models. His contributions have garnered numerous accolades, including a Guggenheim Fellowship, the IEEE Computer Pioneer Award, and an Academy Award for Technical Achievement. He is also a Fellow of several prestigious organizations, including the Royal Society and the IEEE, and continues to influence the field through his research and leadership at VoxelCloud, Inc.

Name: Aradhna Tripati
info: Aradhna Tripati is an American geoscientist and climate scientist currently serving as a professor at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA), where she holds joint appointments in multiple departments and directs the Center for Developing Leadership in Science. Her research focuses on advancing chemical tracers for environmental processes, particularly through clumped isotope geochemistry, to study historical climate change and atmospheric carbon dioxide levels. Notable contributions include her work on reconstructing past temperatures and understanding the dynamics of climate change, as well as her studies on dinosaur body temperatures. Tripati is also an advocate for diversity in STEM fields, actively promoting equity and inclusion through various initiatives and outreach programs. She has received several prestigious awards, including the National Science Foundation CAREER Award and the Presidential Early Career Award in Science and Engineering.

Name: Benjamin S. Williams
info: Benjamin Williams was an influential political figure in North Carolina, serving as the 11th and 14th Governor from 1799 to 1802 and 1807 to 1808, making him one of the few governors to hold nonconsecutive terms. Born in 1751 in Johnston County, he was a farmer and a veteran of the American Revolutionary War, where he rose to the rank of colonel. Williams was active in state politics, serving in both houses of the North Carolina General Assembly and one term in the U.S. House of Representatives. He is noted for his role in the North Carolina Provincial Congress and for pardoning Congressman John Stanly during his governorship. Williams passed away in 1814 and is buried in Moore County, with his former home, House in the Horseshoe, now a historical site.

Name: Stefano Soatto
info: Stefano Soatto is a professor of computer science and electrical engineering at the University of California, Los Angeles, where he also serves as the founding director of the UCLA Vision Lab. He holds a D. Eng. in electrical engineering from the University of Padua and a Ph.D. in control and dynamical systems from the California Institute of Technology. His research primarily focuses on computer vision, machine learning, and robotics, with notable contributions including optimal algorithms for structure from motion and advancements in visual-inertial sensor fusion. Soatto has received several accolades, including the David Marr Prize and recognition as a Fellow of the IEEE and ACM for his work in dynamic visual processes and visual representation learning. He is currently the Vice President of applied science for Amazon Web Services' AI division.

Name: Marc A. Suchard
info: Marc Adam Suchard is an American statistician born on December 23, 1972, in California. He serves as a Professor in the Departments of Biomathematics and Human Genetics at the David Geffen School of Medicine and in the Department of Biostatistics at the UCLA Fielding School of Public Health at UCLA. Suchard is recognized for his contributions to Bayesian statistics and evolutionary modeling, notably through his work on continuous-time Markov chain evolutionary models. He has received several prestigious awards, including the COPSS Presidents' Award in 2013 and the John Simon Guggenheim Fellowship in 2008.

Name: Tatiana Segura
info: Tatiana Segura is an American biomedical engineer and professor at Duke University, where she focuses on developing biomedical engineering solutions to enhance cell growth and tissue repair. Her notable contributions include the creation of hydrogels that act as scaffolds for tissue regeneration, particularly in the brain and skin, and coatings for orthopedic implants that release antibiotics to combat infections. Segura has received several prestigious awards, including the Acta Biomaterialia Silver Medal in 2021 and election as a Fellow of the American Institute for Medical and Biological Engineering in 2017. She previously held a position at the University of California, Los Angeles before joining Duke University in 2018.

Name: Lucina Q. Uddin
info: Lucina Q. Uddin is an American cognitive neuroscientist and professor at the University of California, Los Angeles, where she directs the Center for Cognitive Neuroscience Analysis Core at the Semel Institute for Neuroscience and Behavior. Her research focuses on brain connectivity and cognition, particularly in neurodevelopmental disorders, utilizing network neuroscience approaches. Uddin has made significant contributions to understanding the dynamics of brain networks, particularly through her influential model centered on the insular cortex and salience network, which is detailed in her book "Salience network of the human brain." She has received numerous awards for her work, including the 2013 Slifka Award from the International Society for Autism Research and the 2023 A.E. Bennett Award for Basic Research from the Society of Biological Psychiatry.
